A measurable quantity capable of taking on a number of values .
A variable , often the set of x values plotted on a graph .
To alter ; or vary ; to make different .
a variable quantity that is random

variated.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of variate .

variation.explanation: The act, fact, or process of varying.
The extent or degree to which something varies.
Something different from another of the same type: synonym : difference .
Magnetic declination.
The existence within a species or other group of organisms of differences in form, function, or behavior, especially when hereditary.
A function that relates the values of one variable to those of other variables.
A form that is an altered version of a given theme, diverging from it by melodic ornamentation and by changes in harmony, rhythm, or key.
One of a series of forms based on a single theme.
A solo dance, especially one forming part of a larger work.
The difference of offspring from the parent.

Statistical or formal abnormality in living beings, or the departure of individual organisms from the mean, average, or rule for the race, considered as a fixed standard or logical species which individual animals approach or from which they recede.
A change in a living being which is dne to its own activity as an individual, as contrasted with a change which is inherited. See the extract.

A congenital or germinal change in a living being, which is not due to its own activity and is transmitted to descendants, as contrasted with a change which comes about in it by its own activity and is not transmitted to descendants.
A change that may take place in an individual or a variety or species when its habitat changes.
The amount of change which a quantity suffers in an hour: as, the hourly variation of the sun's declination.
Variation which arises during the larval and later stages of development, as contrasted with variation which arises during the early embryonic stages.
The act or process of varying; partial change in form, position, state, or qualities; alteration; mutation; diversity; variance; modification: as, variations of color; the slow variation of language.

The extent to which a thing varies; the degree, interval, or amount of departure from a former condition, position, or relation; amount or rate of change: as, a variation of two degrees; a variation of twopence in the pound.
Difference.
Variance; dissension; discord.
In grammar , change of form of words, as in declension, conjugation, etc.; inflection.
In astronomy , any deviation from the mean orbit or mean motion of a heavenly body, occasioned by another disturbing body.

In physics and navigation , the deviation of a magnetic needle from the true north, denoted by the angle which the vertical plane passing through the poles of the needle freely suspended, and undisturbed by local attraction, makes with the geographical meridian of the place: generally and more properly called declination .

In biology , the act, process, or result of deviation from a given type of form or structure in a plastic vegetable or animal organization, by means of natural selection; or the sum of the phenomena resulting from the influence of conditions of environment, as opposed to those which would have been exhibited had the law of heredity alone been operative. See variability , 2, and variety , 6.
In music , a tune or theme repeated with changes, elaborations, or embellishments, especially when made one of a series of movements aiming to develop the capacities of a given subject.
In the calculus, an infinitesimal increment of a function, due to changes in the values of the constants, and affecting it, therefore, in different amounts for different values of the variables.
In algebra : The following of a + sign after a—sign, or vice versa, in a row of signs.
A linear arrangement of some of a given set of objects or of all. Thus, there are fifteen variations of the letters A, B, C, as follows: A, B, C, AB, BA, BC, CB, CA, AC, ABC, BCA, CAB, CBA, BAC, ACB.
The act of varying; a partial change in the form, position, state, or qualities of a thing; modification; alteration; mutation; diversity; deviation
Extent to which a thing varies; amount of departure from a position or state; amount or rate of change.
Change of termination of words, as in declension, conjugation, derivation, etc.

Repetition of a theme or melody with fanciful embellishments or modifications, in time, tune, or harmony, or sometimes change of key; the presentation of a musical thought in new and varied aspects, yet so that the essential features of the original shall still preserve their identity.
One of the different arrangements which can be made of any number of quantities taking a certain number of them together.
the yearly change in the right ascension or declination of a star, produced by the combined effects of the precession of the equinoxes and the proper motion of the star.
See under Calculus .
See under Compass .
an inequality of the moon's motion, depending on the angular distance of the moon from the sun. It is greater at the octants, and zero at the quadratures.

the angle included between the true and magnetic meridians of a place; the deviation of the direction of a magnetic needle from the true north and south line; -- called also declination of the needle .

The act or state of varying ; a partial change in the form, position, state, or qualities of a thing; modification ; alternation ; mutation ; diversity ; deviation ; as, a variation of color in different lights; a variation in size; variation of language.
A related but distinct thing.
The angular difference at the vessel between the direction of true north and magnetic north . Also called magnetic declination .
a line of play that differs from the original
a technique where material is repeated with alterations to the melody , harmony , rhythm , timbre , texture , counterpoint or orchestration .
an artifact that deviates from a norm or standard
an activity that varies from a norm or standard
the angle (at a particular location) between magnetic north and true north
a repetition of a musical theme in which it is modified or embellished

variational.explanation: variational fact or doctrine; variational characters: in the latter instance, synonymous with varietal. Encyc.
Of, pertaining to, or caused by variation

variationist.explanation: A person who studies variation in usage among speakers of the same language

variator.explanation: In experimental psychology , the device which secures uniform change of pitch in Stern's tone-variator; in the old pattern of the instrument, the mercury trough; in the new pattern, a metal cam. See tone-variator .

A device for producing desired variations, usually in power or in speed; specifically, in the practice of motor-drawn trains of vehicles on the highway, each unit of which has its own propelling motor, a device attached to the leading and guiding vehicle, by which the limits of speed in each change-gear of the following vehicles may be reduced between determined limits without a resetting of the change-gear lever on each.
A joint used in underground electrical mains to allow for the expansion or contraction of the metal with changes of temperature.

varicated.explanation: conchology , having varices; marked by varicose formations.

varication.explanation: (⟨ NL. varix ( varic -) + - ation. ] In conchology , formation of a varix; a set or system of varices.

varicella.explanation: A specific contagious disease, usually of childhood, characterized by an eruption of vesicles of moderate size, filled with a clear, slightly yellowish fluid; chicken-pox: swine-pox.
an acute contagious disease caused by herpes varicella zoster virus; causes a rash of vesicles on the face and body

varicelliform.explanation: That resembles a varicella ( chicken pox ) rash

varicoblepharon.explanation: A varicose tumor of the eyelid.

varicocele.explanation: A varicose condition of veins of the spermatic cord or the ovaries, forming a soft tumor.
A tumor in the scrotum, composed of the varicosed veins of the spermatic cord. The term was employed by the older medical writers to designate also a varicose condition of the scrotal veins.
A varicose enlargement of the veins of the spermatic cord; also, a like enlargement of the veins of the scrotum.
Varicose veins in the area of the scrotum
dilatation of the veins associated with the spermatic cord in the testes

varicolored.explanation: Having a variety of colors; variegated.
Having a variety of colors ; variegated or motley .
having sections or patches colored differently and usually brightly

varicoloured.explanation: having sections or patches colored differently and usually brightly

varicose.explanation: Characterized by or resulting from varicose veins.
zoöl , rominent and tortuous, as formations upon a shell; resembling or having varices; varicated
Irregularly swollen or enlarged; affected with, or containing, varices, or varicosities; of or pertaining to varices, or varicosities.
Intended for the treatment of varicose veins; -- said of elastic stockings, bandages, and the like.

varicoseness.explanation: The state of being varicose; a condition of dilatation and tortuousness.

varicosis.explanation: The occurrence of varicose veins; varicosity.
The condition of being varicose or of having varicose veins
pathological condition of being varicose or having varicose veins

varicosity.explanation: The condition of having varicose veins.
The quality or state of being varicose.
An enlargement or swelling in a vessel, fiber, or the like; a varix.
An enlarged vessel or nerve, particularly a blood vessel.
varix or varicose condition in which a vein is swollen and tortuous

varicotomy.explanation: An operation for the division of varicose veins.
The surgical procedure of removing varicose veins .

varied.explanation: Having or consisting of various kinds or forms; diverse: synonym : miscellaneous .
Simple past tense and past participle of vary .
broken away from sameness or identity or duplication

variegate.explanation: To change the appearance of, especially by marking with different colors.
To give variety to; make varied.
variegate a floor with marble of different colors.
To diversify in external appearance; to mark with different colors; to dapple; to streak.
to add variety to something; to diversify
to change the appearance of something, especially by covering with patches or streaks of different colour
change the appearance of, especially by marking with different colors
make something more diverse and varied

variegated.explanation: Having streaks, marks, or patches of a different color or colors; varicolored.
Distinguished or characterized by variety; diversified.
Having marks or patches of different colors.
Streaked , spotted , or otherwise marked with a variety of color; very colorful.
Simple past tense and past participle of variegate .

variegates.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of variegate .

variegation.explanation: Varied coloration; the conjunction of various colors or color-marks; party-coloration.
In botany : The conjunction of two or more colors in the petals, leaves, and other parts of plants.
A condition of plants in which the leaves become partially white or of a very light color, from suppression or modification of the chlorophyl.
The act of variegating or diversifying, or the state of being diversified, by different colors; diversity of colors.
a variation in the colour of different zones of the same plant
the act of introducing variety (especially in investments or in the variety of goods and services offered)

variegator.explanation: One who or that which variegates.

varier.explanation: One who varies; one who deviates.
A wanderer; one who strays in search of variety.
A wanderer; one who strays in search of variety.

varies.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of vary .

varietal.explanation: Of, indicating, or characterizing a variety, especially a biological variety.
A wine made principally from one variety of grape and carrying the name of that grape.
petrography , in the quantitative classification of igneous rocks (see rock ), having the character of or producing a variety of a mode.

biology , having the character of a zoölogical or botanical variety; subspecific, or of the character of a subspecies; racial, with reference to geographical variation; of or pertaining to varieties: variational: as, varietal characters; varietal differences or distinctions. See variability , 2. variation , 8, and variety , 6.
Of or pertaining to a variety; characterizing a variety; constituting a variety, in distinction from an individual or species.
Pertaining to a distinct variety of organism.
Made from a single specific variety (especially of grapes in wine).
A wine made primarily from or exclusively from a single variety of grape, which carries the name of that grape.
By extension, a coffee made primarily from or exclusively from a single variety of coffee bean.
a wine made principally from one grape and carrying the name of that grape

varietally.explanation: biology , in a varietal manner or relation; as a variety; to a varietal extent only; subspecifically.

varietist.explanation: A person who enjoys sexual variety

variety.explanation: The quality or condition of being various or varied; diversity.
A number or collection of varied things, especially of a particular group; an assortment.
Something that is distinguished from others of the same kind by a specific characteristic or set of characteristics.
A form of a language that is used by a specific social group and differs from forms used by other social groups.

A taxonomic subdivision of a species or subspecies consisting of a group of naturally occurring or selectively bred individuals that differ from other individuals of the species in certain minor characteristics.
A variety show.

In agriculture and horticulture , a group of cultivated plants which have the same characteristics. All plants which have been widely cultivated have given rise to many different forms and these are in general known as varieties. Illustrations are the varieties of strawberries, apples, corn, wheat, cotton, etc. ‘Variety,’ in this sense, is thus a generic word including races, strains, and clons. See race , 5 , strain , 1 , and clon .
In petrography , in the quantitative classification of igneous rocks (see rock ), a division of a mode which recognizes the presence of subordinate mineral components.

The state or character of being varied or various; intermixture of different things, or of things different in form, or a succession of different things; diversity; multifariousness; absence of monotony or uniformity; dissimilitude.
Exhibition of different characteristics by one individual; many-sidedness; versatility.
Variation; deviation; change.
A collection of different things; a varied assortment.

Something differing from others of the same general kind; one of many things which agree in their general features; a sort; a kind: as, varieties of rock, of wood, of land, of soil; to prefer one variety of cloth to another.

In biology , with special reference to classification: A subspecies; a subdivision of a species; an individual animal or plant which differs, or collectively those individuals which differ, from the rest of its or their species, in certain recognizable particulars which are transmissible, and constant to a degree, yet which are not specifically distinctive, since they intergrade with the characters of other members of the same species; a race, especially a climatic or geographical race which arises without man's interference. See species , 5.
The quality or state of being various; intermixture or succession of different things; diversity; multifariousness.
That which is various.
A number or collection of different things; a varied assortment.
Something varying or differing from others of the same general kind; one of a number of things that are akin; a sort.

An individual, or group of individuals, of a species differing from the rest in some one or more of the characteristics typical of the species, and capable either of perpetuating itself for a period, or of being perpetuated by artificial means; hence, a subdivision, or peculiar form, of a species.
In inorganic nature, one of those forms in which a species may occur, which differ in minor characteristics of structure, color, purity of composition, etc.
Such entertainment as in given in variety shows; the production of, or performance in, variety shows.
a variety of any species which is coincident with a geographical region, and is usually dependent upon, or caused by, peculiarities of climate.
a cross between two individuals of different varieties of the same species; a mongrel.
A specific variation of something
A state of constant change
A rank in a taxonomic classification , below species and subspecies .
The total number of distinct states of a system .
Logarithm of the base 2 of the total number of distinct states of a system .
a term used for a specific form of a language, neutral to whether that form is a dialect , accent , register , etc. and to its prestige level.
The class of all algebraic structures of a given signature satisfying a given set of identities .
a collection containing a variety of sorts of things
a category of things distinguished by some common characteristic or quality
noticeable heterogeneity
a difference that is usually pleasant
a show consisting of a series of short unrelated performances
(biology) a taxonomic category consisting of members of a species that differ from others of the same species in minor but heritable characteristics

variform.explanation: Having a variety of forms; diversiform.

variformed.explanation: Formed with different shapes; having various forms; variform.

varify.explanation: To make different; to vary; to variegate.
To make different ; to vary or variegate .

varigradation.explanation: In phys. geol. , alternate aggradation and degradation by a stream in successive parts of its course.

variola.explanation: The pustular apothecium occurring on certain lichens.

Smallpox; a specific contagious disease characterized by an eruption of papules, becoming vesicular and then pustular, and attended by high fever, racking pains in the head and spine, and severe constitutional disturbance.
a highly contagious viral disease characterized by fever and weakness and skin eruption with pustules that form scabs that slough off leaving scars

variolaria.explanation: An old pseudogenus of lichens, the species of which are variously disposed.

variolate.explanation: Having pustules or marks like those of smallpox.
To inoculate with the smallpox virus.
pathology , marked as if by smallpox.
entomology , resembling a scar of smallpox: noting impressions or foveæ when they have a central prominence.
botany , thickly marked with pustules or pits, as in smallpox.

variolation.explanation: Inoculation with the virus of smallpox. See inoculation , Also variolization .
The inoculation of a person with smallpox so as to induce a mild form of the illness and subsequent immunity to it.
the obsolete process of inoculating a susceptible person with material taken from a vesicle of a person who has smallpox

variole.explanation: In zoology , a shallow pit, or slightly pitted marking, like the pitting of a smallpox-pustule; a foveole.
In lithoh. , a spherulite of the rock called variolite.

variolite.explanation: A basic rock whose pockmarked appearance is caused by the presence of numerous white, rounded, embedded spherules.

A rock in which there is a more or less distinctly concretionary arrangement, giving rise to pustular or pea-like forms which are disseminated through a finely crystalline ground-mass, and which, from their resemblance as seen on weathered surfaces to smallpox-pustules, have for hundreds of years made this rock an object of curiosity.
A kind of diorite or diabase containing imbedded whitish spherules, which give the rock a spotted appearance.
A kind of diorite or diabase with embedded whitish spherules , which give the rock a spotted appearance.

variolitic.explanation: lithoh. pertaining to, resembling, or containing variolite.
Thickly marked with small, round specks; spotted.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, variolite.
Thickly marked with small, round specks ; spotted .
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, variolite .

variolitization.explanation: In lithology , conversion into variolite; change in a rock of such a character as to give rise to the peculiar structure denominated variolitic.

variolization.explanation: Variolation : inoculation against smallpox using material from a smallpox lesion
the obsolete process of inoculating a susceptible person with material taken from a vesicle of a person who has smallpox

varioloid.explanation: A mild form of smallpox occurring in people who have been previously vaccinated or who have had the disease.
Modified smallpox; a mild form of smallpox which may abort at the vesicular stage, occurring usually in those who are partially protected by vaccination.
The smallpox as modified by previous inoculation or vaccination.
Resembling smallpox; pertaining to the disease called varioloid.
A milder outbreak of smallpox occurring in a person who has previously been infected.

variolous.explanation: Of, relating to, or affected with smallpox.
entomology , having somewhat scattered and irregular varioles.
Of or pertaining to the smallpox; having pits, or sunken impressions, like those of the smallpox; variolar; variolic.

variometer.explanation: A variable inductor used to measure variations in terrestrial magnetism.
An instrument used in comparing the intensity of magnetic forces, especially the magnetic force of the earth at different points—for example, as varied by local causes.
An instrument for comparing magnetic forces, esp. in the earth's magnetic field.
An instrument used to measure variations in a magnetic field
a measuring instrument for measuring variations in a magnetic field

variorum.explanation: An edition of the works of an author with notes by various scholars or editors.
An edition containing various versions of a text.
Of or relating to a variorum edition or text.
Containing notes by different persons; -- applied to a publication.
An edition of a written work (especially the complete works of a classical writer) showing the notes and readings of a variety of different editors or commentators.
an edition containing various versions of a text or notes by various scholars or editors

various.explanation: Varied in nature or character; not uniform.
having a broad range (of different elements).
of many different kinds purposefully arranged but lacking any uniformity

variousness.explanation: The character or state of being various; variety; multifariousness.
The state or property of being various .

variscite.explanation: A rare, light to dark or bluish green, translucent mineral, Al(PO 4 ) · 2H 2 O, found in aluminum-rich rocks and sometimes used as a semiprecious stone.
A hydrous phosphate of aluminium, occurring in crystalline or reniform crusts of a bright-green color.
An apple-green mineral occurring in reniform masses. It is a hydrous phosphate of alumina.
A relatively rare hydrated aluminum phosphate mineral (AlPO4·2H2O), sometimes confused with turquoise .

varisse.explanation: Blood-spavin in the horse; an enlargement or varicose condition of the vein on the inside of the hock-joint.
An imperfection on the inside of the hind leg in horses, different from a curb, but at the same height, and often growing to an unsightly size.

varistor.explanation: An electronic component having a variable resistance ; used to protect circuits against power surges .

varix.explanation: An abnormally dilated or swollen vein, artery, or lymph vessel.
One of the longitudinal ridges on the surface of a gastropod shell.
Abnormal dilatation or tortuosity of a vein or other vessel of the body; also, a vein, artery, or lymphatic thus dilated or tortuous; a varicose vessel.

[NL.] In conchology , a mark or scar on the surface of a shell denoting a former position of the lip of the aperture, which has passed on with the periodical growth of the shell. Varices are conspicuous in some univalves. See cuts under murex and triton.
A uneven, permanent dilatation of a vein.
One of the prominent ridges or ribs extending across each of the whorls of certain univalve shells.
a varicose , i.e. swollen and knotted , vein
abnormally enlarged or twisted blood vessel or lymphatic vessel

varlet.explanation: Originally, a very young man of noble or knightly birth, serving an apprenticeship in knightly exercises and accomplishments while awaiting elevation to the rank of knight; hence (because such youths served as pages or personal servants to the knights who had charge of them), a body-servant or attendant. (See valet .) The name was also given to the city bailiffs or Serjeants.
Hence, one in a subordinate or menial position; a low fellow; a scoundrel; a rascal; a rogue: a term of contempt or reproach.
The coat-card now called the knave or jack (in French, valet ).
A servant, especially to a knight; an attendant; a valet; a footman.
Hence, a low fellow; a scoundrel; a rascal.
In a pack of playing cards, the court card now called the knave , or jack .
Specifically, a youth acting as a knight's attendant at the beginning of his training for knighthood.
in medieval times a youth acting as a knight's attendant as the first stage in training for knighthood

varletess.explanation: A female varlet; a waiting-woman. Richardson , Clarissa Harlowe, I. xxxi.

varletry.explanation: A crowd of attendants or menials.
The rabble; the crowd; the mob.
The rabble; the crowd; the mob.
The rabble ; the crowd ; the mob .

varment.explanation: any usually predatory wild animal considered undesirable; e.g., coyote

varmint.explanation: One that is considered undesirable, obnoxious, or troublesome.
A pestering animal such as one that kills or harasses a farmer's livestock.
A person who is obnoxious or makes trouble.
any usually predatory wild animal considered undesirable; e.g., coyote

varna.explanation: any of the four original castes in Hinduism , or the system of such castes

varnish.explanation: A liquid that contains a solvent and an oxidizing or evaporating binder and is applied to a surface to produce a hard, transparent finish after evaporation and curing.
The smooth coating or gloss resulting from the application of this liquid.
Something suggestive of or resembling varnish.
An often deceptive external appearance or outward show.
To cover with varnish.
To give a smooth and glossy finish to.
To give a superficial or deceptive appearance to.
In etching , any resinous coating used to cover parts of the plate which have become exposed: to be distinguished from the ground , which is the original coating applied to the entire plate.
varnish , n., 1.
varnish errors or deformity.

A solution of resinous matter, forming a clear limpid fluid capable of hardening without losing its transparency: used by painters, gilders, cabinet-makers, and others for coating over the surface of their work in order to give it a shining, transparent, and hard surface, capable of resisting in a greater or less degree the influences of air and moisture.
That which resembles varnish, either naturally or artificially: a glossy or lustrous appearance.
An artificial covering to give a fair appearance to any act or conduct; outside show; gloss; palliation; “whitewash.”
In ceramics , the glaze of pottery or porcelain.

A viscid liquid, consisting of a solution of resinous matter in an oil or a volatile liquid, laid on work with a brush, or otherwise. When applied the varnish soon dries, either by evaporation or chemical action, and the resinous part forms thus a smooth, hard surface, with a beautiful gloss, capable of resisting, to a greater or less degree, the influences of air and moisture.
That which resembles varnish, either naturally or artificially; a glossy appearance.
An artificial covering to give a fair appearance to any act or conduct; outside show; gloss.

a tree or shrub from the juice or resin of which varnish is made, as some species of the genus Rhus, especially Rhus vernicifera of Japan. The black varnish of Burmah is obtained from the Melanorrhœa usitatissima , a tall East Indian tree of the Cashew family. See Copal , and Mastic .
To lay varnish on; to cover with a liquid which produces, when dry, a hard, glossy surface.
To cover or conceal with something that gives a fair appearance; to give a fair coloring to by words; to gloss over; to palliate.
A type of paint with a solvent that evaporates to leave a hard , transparent , glossy film .
Anything resembling such a paint.
By extension: A deceptively showy appearance .
To apply varnish.
To cover up with varnish.
To gloss over a defect .
cover with varnish
a coating that provides a hard, lustrous, transparent finish to a surface

varnished.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of varnish .
having a coating of stain or varnish

varnisher.explanation: One who varnishes, or whose occupation is to varnish.
One who disguises or palliates; one who gives a fair external appearance (to); one who glosses over.
One who varnishes; one whose occupation is to varnish.
One who disguises or palliates; one who gives a fair external appearance.
Agent noun of varnish ; one who varnishes.
someone who applies a finishing coat of varnish

varnishing.explanation: The act of laying on varnish; also, materials for varnish.

varsity.explanation: The principal team representing a university, college, or school in sports, games, or other competitions.
A reduction of univarsity for university : used in English universities, and affected to some extent in American colleges.

the team with the best players of a school or club, being the main representative of the organization in competitive play between schools or organizations. In schools, contrasted with junior varsity . Also used attributively, .
a team representing a college or university
a British abbreviation of `university'; usually refers to Oxford University or Cambridge University

varsovienne.explanation: A dance which apparently originated in France about 1853, in imitation of the Polish mazurka, polka, and redowa.
Music for such a dance, or in its rhythm, which is triple and rather slow, with strong accent on the first beat of every second measure.
Music for such a dance or having its slow triple time characteristic strong accent beginning every second measure.

vartabed.explanation: A doctor or teacher in the Armenian Apostolic Church, often in charge of a diocese .

varus.explanation: An abnormal position of a bone of the leg or foot.
A deformity characterized by inversion of the foot. See talipes varus .
[ capitalized ] [NL. (Stål, 1865).] A genus of hemipterous insects
A deformity in which the foot is turned inward. See talipes .
a deformity in which part of a limb is turned inward to an abnormal degree

varve.explanation: A layer or series of layers of sediment deposited in a body of still water in one year.
An annual layer of sediment or sedimentary rock .

vary.explanation: To undergo or show change.
To deviate from a standard or expectation.
To have a range of different qualities or amounts.
To make or cause changes in; modify or alter.
To give variety to; make diverse.
Alteration; change; variation.
vary the conditions of an experiment.
music , to embellish or alter (a melody or theme) without really changing its identity. See variation , 9.
vary.
math, analysis , to be subject to continual increase or decrease: as, a quantity conceived to vary , or have different values in the same equation.
biology , to be varied or subject to variation, as by natural or artificial selection; exhibit variation. See variability , 2, variation , 8, and variety , 6.
Alteration; change.
To change the aspect of; to alter in form, appearance, substance, position, or the like; to make different by a partial change; to modify
To change to something else; to transmute; to exchange; to alternate.
To make of different kinds; to make different from one another; to diversify; to variegate.
To embellish; to change fancifully; to present under new aspects, as of form, key, measure, etc. See Variation , 4.
To alter, or be altered, in any manner; to suffer a partial change; to become different; to be modified.
To differ, or be different; to be unlike or diverse.
To alter or change in succession; to alternate.
To deviate; to depart; to swerve; -- followed by from.
To disagree; to be at variance or in dissension.
To change with time or a similar parameter .
To institute a change in, from a current state; to modify .
Not to remain constant : to change with time or a similar parameter.
To display differences .
To be or act different from the usual .
Alteration; change.
be subject to change in accordance with a variable
make something more diverse and varied
become different in some particular way, without permanently losing one's or its former characteristics or essence
be at variance with; be out of line with

vas.explanation: In anatomy and zoology , a vas-culum or vessel, as a tube, duct, or conduit conveying blood, lymph, or other fluid
The aberrant ducts of the testis. See aberrant .
Bile-ducts running an unusual course in the liver.
Tributaries to the splenic vein, corresponding to the arterial vasa brevia.
The efferent lymphatic vessels: usually small ones, that soon unite into a larger one.
The excretory duct of a testicle; a spermatic duct.
A vessel or duct transporting any bodily fluid, such as blood , lymph , chyle , or semen .
a tube in which a body fluid circulates

vasal.explanation: Of, relating to, or connected with a vessel or duct of the body.

vasalled.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of vasal .

vascular.explanation: Of, characterized by, or containing cells or vessels that carry or circulate fluids, such as blood, lymph, or sap, through the body of an animal or plant.

anatomy and zoology : Of or pertaining to vessels which convey fluids; of or pertaining to the conveyance or circulation of fluids, especially blood, lymph, and chyle; circulatory: as, the vascular system; a vascular function or action.
vascular tissues; cartilage and cuticle are non-vascular; a vascular tumor.
botany : Consisting of, relating to, or furnished with vessels or ducts: applied to the tissues of plants that are composed of or furnished with elongated cells or vessels for the circulation of sap.
botany , tissue composed of vessels or ducts; the fibrovascular system.
Consisting of, or containing, vessels as an essential part of a structure; full of vessels; specifically (Bot.), pertaining to, or containing, special ducts, or tubes, for the circulation of sap.
Operating by means of, or made up of an arrangement of, vessels
Of or pertaining to the vessels of animal and vegetable bodies.
Of or pertaining to the higher division of plants, that is, the phænogamous plants, all of which are vascular, in distinction from the cryptogams, which to a large extent are cellular only.
plants composed in part of vascular tissue, as all flowering plants and the higher cryptogamous plants, or those of the class Pteridophyta. Cf. Cellular plants, under Cellular .
the body of associated ducts and woody fiber; the fibrovascular part of plants.
vegetable tissue composed partly of ducts, or sap tubes.

a system of vessels in annelids, nemerteans, and many other invertebrates, containing a circulating fluid analogous to blood, but not of the same composition. In annelids the fluid which they contain is usually red, but in some it is green, in others yellow, or whitish.
Of, pertaining to, or containing vessels that conduct or circulate fluids, such as blood , lymph , or sap , through the body of an animal or plant.
of or relating to or having vessels that conduct and circulate fluids

vascularity.explanation: The character or condition of being vascular.
The quality or state of being vascular.
: The degree to which the veins in a body part are visible.

vascularization.explanation: The process of vascularizing; the formation of vessels, especially blood vessels.
An abnormal or pathological formation of blood vessels.
The process of becoming vascular, as by the formation of new bloodvessels.
The process of becoming vascular, or the condition of being vascular; as, the vascularization of cartilege.
the formation of blood vessels and capillaries in living tissue
the organic process whereby body tissue becomes vascular and develops capillaries

vascularize.explanation: To supply with, or to acquire vessels (that conduct fluid)
become vascular and have vessels that circulate fluids

vascularized.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of vascularize .

vasculature.explanation: Arrangement of blood vessels in the body or in an organ or body part.
The arrangement of blood vessels in the body, or within an organ.

vasculiform.explanation: botany , having the form of a vessel like a flowerpot.

vasculitis.explanation: Inflammation of a vessel of the body.
Inflammation of a lymph- or blood-vessel.
A group of diseases featuring inflammation of the wall of blood vessels .

vasculogenesis.explanation: The formation and development of the vascular system, including the formation of blood vessels from endothelial cells .

vasculose.explanation: In chem. , the substance constituting the principal part of the vessels of plants.
One of the substances of which vegetable tissue is composed, differing from cellulose in respect to its solubility in certain media.
One of the substances of which vegetable tissue is composed, differing from cellulose in its solubility in certain media.

vasculum.explanation: A usually metal case used for carrying collected plant specimens.
A botanist's case or box for carrying specimens as he collects them.
In anatomy : A small vessel; a vas.
A tin box, commonly cylindrical or flattened, used in collecting plants.
A container used by botanists to keep samples viable by maintaining a cool , humid environment .

vase.explanation: An open container, as of glass or porcelain, used for holding flowers or for ornamentation.
A hollow vessel, generally high in proportion to its horizontal diameter, and decorative in character and purpose.
Hence An object designed usually for ornament, but sometimes for other specific purposes, having somewhat the form and appearance of the vessel in the primary sense.
The body of the Corinthian and Composite capital: sometimes called tambour or drum.

A vessel adapted for various domestic purposes, and anciently for sacrificial uses; especially, a vessel of antique or elegant pattern used for ornament; See Illust. of Portland vase, under Portland .

A vessel similar to that described in the first definition above, or the representation of one in a solid block of stone, or the like, used for an ornament, as on a terrace or in a garden. See Illust. of Niche .
The body, or naked ground, of the Corinthian and Composite capital; -- called also tambour , and drum .
A container used mainly for displaying fresh, dried, or artificial flowers .
an open jar of glass or porcelain used as an ornament or to hold flowers

vasectomized.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of vasectomize .

vasectomy.explanation: Surgical removal of all or part of the vas deferens, usually as a means of sterilization.
Resection or excision of the vas deferens.
The surgical removal of all or part of the vas deferens , usually as a means of male sterilization .
surgical procedure that removes all or part of the vas deferens (usually as a means of sterilization); is sometimes reversible

vaseful.explanation: The quantity that a vase will contain.
As much as a vase will hold.

vaselike.explanation: Resembling a vase or some aspect of one.

vaseline.explanation: Petroleum jelly (now sold by Unilever) under the trade name Vaseline .
Any petroleum jelly or similar lubricant .
A greenish-yellow coloured glass , or the colouring used in the manufacture of this glass.

vashegyite.explanation: An orthorhombic-pyramidal mineral containing aluminum , hydrogen , oxygen , and phosphorus .

vasicine.explanation: An alkaloid contained in the leaves of Adhatoda vasica Nees , from the Panjab. It is intensely poisonous to the lower forms of animal life, but has no appreciable effect on normal animals of higher orders. The natives use the leaves of the plant as a remedy in affections of the respiratory organs.

vasiform.explanation: Having the form of a vessel, or duct.
Having the form of a vessel or duct .
constituting a tube; having hollow tubes (as for the passage of fluids)

vasoactive.explanation: Causing constriction or dilation of blood vessels.
That causes either constriction or dilation of a blood vessel

vasoconstriction.explanation: Constriction of a blood vessel, as by a nerve or drug.
Contraction of the blood-vessels; a narrowing of the lumen of the veins or arteries.
decrease in the diameter of blood vessels

vasoconstrictive.explanation: any agent that causes a narrowing of an opening of a blood vessel: cold or stress or nicotine or epinephrine or norepinephrine or angiotensin or vasopressin or certain drugs; maintains or increases blood pressure

vasoconstrictor.explanation: Something, such as a nerve or drug, that causes vasoconstriction.
vasodilator. Both are included under vasomotor.
That which causes contraction of the blood-vessels: applied to nerves and to certain drugs.
Causing constriction of the blood vessels; These nerves are also called vasohypertonic .
A substance which causes constriction of the blood vessels. Such substances are used in medicine to raise abnormally low blood pressure.

any agent that causes a narrowing of an opening of a blood vessel: cold or stress or nicotine or epinephrine or norepinephrine or angiotensin or vasopressin or certain drugs; maintains or increases blood pressure

vasocorona.explanation: The system of blood-vessels supplying the spinal cord which pass from the surface toward the center.

vasodentine.explanation: A vascular form of dentine in which blood circulates; dentine whose capillaries are large enough for the passage of red blood-disks. Compare osteodentine and vitriodentine.
A modified form of dentine, which is permeated by blood capillaries; vascular dentine.
A modified form of dentine , which is permeated by blood capillaries ; vascular dentine.

vasodilation.explanation: Dilation of a blood vessel, as by the action of a nerve or drug.
dilation of blood vessels (especially the arteries)

vasodilator.explanation: Something, such as a nerve or drug, that causes vasodilation.
That which causes dilatation of the blood-vessels: applied to nerves and certain drugs.
A substance which causes dilation of blood vessels.
Causing dilation or relaxation of the blood vessels. These nerves are also called vaso-inhibitory , and vasohypotonic nerves, since their stimulation causes relaxation and rest.
A drug or chemical agent that causes dilation of the blood vessels thereby reducing blood pressure .
a drug that causes dilation of blood vessels

vasoepididymostomy.explanation: A kind of surgery by which vasectomies are reversed , involving connection of the severed vas deferens to the epididymis .

vasoformative.explanation: Concerned in the development and formation of blood vessels and blood corpuscles.
Of or pertaining to the formation and development of blood vessels and blood cells

vasoganglion.explanation: A network or knot of vessels; a vascular rete.

vasoligation.explanation: Surgical ligation of the vas deferens as a means of sterilization.

vasomotion.explanation: Increase or diminution of the caliber of a vessel, usually a blood-vessel.
A change in the diameter ( caliber ) of a blood vessel

vasomotor.explanation: Relating to, causing, or regulating constriction or dilation of blood vessels.
Causing movement in the walls of vessels

the chief dominating or general center which supplies all the unstriped muscles of the arterial system with motor nerves, situated in a part of the medulla oblongata; a center of reflex action by the working of which afferent impulses are changed into efferent, -- vasomotor impulses leading either to dilation or constriction of the blood vessels.
Of or pertaining to the regulation of the diameter of blood vessels .
relating to the nerves and muscles that cause the blood vessels to constrict or dilate

vasopressin.explanation: A hormone secreted by the posterior lobe of the pituitary gland that constricts blood vessels, raises blood pressure, and reduces excretion of urine.
An antidiuretic hormone secreted by the pituitary gland

hormone secreted by the posterior pituitary gland (trade name Pitressin) and also by nerve endings in the hypothalamus; affects blood pressure by stimulating capillary muscles and reduces urine flow by affecting reabsorption of water by kidney tubules

vasopressor.explanation: Of, relating to, or causing constriction of blood vessels.
An agent that causes a rise in blood pressure.
Of or relating to the constriction on blood vessels which eventually causes a rise in blood pressure
an agent that causes such constriction
any agent that produces vasoconstriction and a rise in blood pressure (usually understood as increased arterial pressure)

vasosection.explanation: surgical incision into or division of the vas deferens

vasospasm.explanation: A sudden constriction of a blood vessel, causing a reduction in blood flow.
Spasm of the blood vessels , leading to vasoconstriction and potentially tissue ischemia and necrosis .

vasotocin.explanation: An oligopeptide with properties similar to oxytocin and vasopressin .

vasotomy.explanation: surgical incision into or division of the vas deferens

vasovagal.explanation: Relating to or involving blood vessels and the vagus nerve.
Pertaining to the vagus nerve as well as the vascular system; often describing an attack etc. characterised by slowing of the pulse and a fall in blood pressure.

vassal.explanation: A person who held land from a feudal lord and received protection in return for homage and allegiance.

A feudatory tenant; one holding lands by the obligation to render military service or its equivalent to his superior, especially in contradistinction to rear vassal and vavasor ; a vassal of the first order—that is, one holding directly from the king. Compare great vassal , below.
A subject; a dependent; a retainer; a servant; one who attends on or does the will of another.
The grantee of a fief, feud, or fee; one who holds land of a superior, and who vows fidelity and homage to him; a feudatory; a feudal tenant.
A subject; a dependent; a servant; a bondman; a slave.
the vassal of a vassal; an arriere vassal.
To treat as a vassal; to subject to control; to enslave.
The grantee of a fief , feud , or fee ; one who keeps land of a superior, and who vows fidelity and homage to him, normally a lord of a manor ; a feudatory ; a feudal tenant .
A subject ; a dependant ; a servant ; a slave .
To treat as a vassal or to reduce to the position of a vassal; to subject to control; to enslave .
To subordinate to someone or something.
a person holding a fief; a person who owes allegiance and service to a feudal lord

vassalage.explanation: The condition of being a vassal.
The service, homage, and fealty required of a vassal.
A position of subordination or subjection; servitude.
The land held by a vassal; a fief.
Vassals, especially those of a particular lord, considered as a group.
The state of being a vassal or feudatory; hence, the obligations of that state; the service required of a vassal.
A territory held in vassalage; a fee or fief.
Preëminence, as of one having vassals; hence, valor; prowess; courage.
The state of being a vassal, or feudatory.
Valorous service, such as that performed by a vassal; valor; prowess; courage.
The state of being a vassal .

grow like a plant
