lead a passive existence without using one's body or mind
grow or spread abnormally

vegetated.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of vegetate .

vegetates.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of vegetate .

vegetation.explanation: The plants of an area or a region; plant life.
The act or process of vegetating.
An abnormal growth on a body part.

In phytogeography , the sum total, or a local aggregate, of plant individuals, often of many species, viewed with reference to their ecological adjustment to each other and to all the efficient factors of their environment: contrasted with flora , which denotes a scheme of species rather than a sum of individuals.
The act or process of vegetating; the process of growing exhibited by plants.
In pathology , an excrescence or growth on any surface of the body.
The act or process of vegetating, or growing as a plant does; vegetable growth.
The sum of vegetable life; vegetables or plants in general.
An exuberant morbid outgrowth upon any part, especially upon the valves of the heart.
a crystalline growth of an arborescent form.
An abnormal verrucous or fibrinous growth
all the plant life in a particular region or period
an abnormal growth or excrescence (especially a warty excrescence on the valves of the heart)
inactivity that is passive and monotonous, comparable to the inactivity of plant life
the process of growth in plants

vegetative.explanation: Of, relating to, or characteristic of plants or their growth.
Of, relating to, or capable of growth.
Of, relating to, or functioning in processes such as growth or nutrition rather than reproduction.
Of or relating to asexual reproduction, such as fission or budding.
Spending much time sitting or lying down; physically inactive.
Of or relating to an impaired level of brain function in which a person responds to certain sensory stimuli but demonstrates no cognitive function.

animal physiol. , noting those functions or organs of the body which, being performed or acting unconsciously or involuntarily, are likened to the processes of vegetable growth, as digestion, circulation, secretion, and excretion, which are particularly concerned in the nutrition or in the growth, waste, and repair of the organism: opposed to the specially ani mal functions, as locomotion, cerebration, etc.
vegetative properties of soil.
A vegetable.
Growing, or having the power of growing, as plants; capable of vegetating.
Having the power to produce growth in plants.
Having relation to growth or nutrition; partaking of simple growth and enlargement of the systems of nutrition, apart from the sensorial or distinctively animal functions; vegetal.
Of, or relating to plants ; especially to their growth .
Of, or relating to functions such as growth, nutrition and asexual reproduction rather than sexual reproduction.
Physically inactive .
Of a state of impaired brain function, where a person can respond to some stimuli but is incapable of voluntary acts .
composed of vegetation or plants
relating to involuntary bodily functions
(of reproduction) characterized by asexual processes
of or relating to an activity that is passive and monotonous

vegetatively.explanation: In a vegetative manner; without sexual reproduction.

vegetativeness.explanation: The character of being vegetative, in any sense.

vegetive.explanation: Having the nature of a plant; vegetable.
of or relating to an activity that is passive and monotonous

vehemence.explanation: The character or state of being vehement; the energy exhibited by one who or that which is vehement.
Force or impetuosity accompanying energetic action of any kind; impetuous force; impetuosity; boisterousness; violence; fury: as, the vehemence of wind; to speak with vehemence.
The quality or state of being vehement; impetuous force; impetuosity; violence; fury.
Violent ardor; great heat; animated fervor.
An intense concentration , force or power .
A wild or turbulent ferocity or fury .
the property of being wild or turbulent

vehement.explanation: Characterized by forcefulness of expression or intensity of emotion or conviction; fervid.
Impetuous, fiery, burning, hot, fervid, forcible, vigorous, boisterous.
Acting with great force; furious; violent; impetuous; forcible; mighty.
Very ardent; very eager or urgent; very fervent; passionate.
Showing strong feelings; passionate ; forceful or intense .
marked by extreme intensity of emotions or convictions; inclined to react violently; fervid
characterized by great force or energy

vehemently.explanation: In a vehement manner; expressing with a strong or forceful attitude.

vehicle.explanation: A device or structure for transporting persons or things; a conveyance.
A self-propelled conveyance that runs on tires; a motor vehicle.
A medium through which something is transmitted, expressed, or accomplished.
The concrete or specific word or phrase that is applied to the tenor of a metaphor and gives the metaphor its figurative power, as walking shadow in
A play, role, or piece of music used to display the special talents of one performer or company.
An inactive substance that is combined with an active medication to facilitate administration.
A substance, such as oil, in which paint pigments are mixed for application.
In chem. , a liquid used to carry sensitive salts for coating glass or paper for use in photography.
Any carriage moving on land, either on wheels or on runners; a conveyance.
That which is used as an instrument of conveyance, transmission, or communication.
Specifically— In pharmacy , a substance, usually fluid, possessing little or no medicinal action, used as a medium for the administration of active remedies; an excipient.
In painting , any liquid, whether water, as in water-color painting, or oil, as in oil-color painting, which is used to render colors, varnishes, etc., manageable and fit for use.
One of two enduements, the one more spiritual than the other, with which the soul is clothed, according to the Platonists. One corresponds to vital power, the other to spirit.
That in or on which any person or thing is, or may be, carried, as a coach, carriage, wagon, cart, car, sleigh, bicycle, etc.; a means of conveyance; specifically, a means of conveyance upon land.
That which is used as the instrument of conveyance or communication.
A substance in which medicine is taken.
Any liquid with which a pigment is applied, including whatever gum, wax, or glutinous or adhesive substance is combined with it.
A liquid used to spread sensitive salts upon glass and paper for use in photography.
A conveyance ; a device for carrying or transporting substances , objects or individuals .
A medium for expression of talent or views .
A liquid content (e.g. oil) which acts as a binding and drying agent in paint. (FM 55-501).
An entity to achieve an end.
A yana .
An animal or (rarely) a plant on which a Hindu deity rides or sits
a conveyance that transports people or objects
any substance that facilitates the use of a drug or pigment or other material that is mixed with it
a medium for the expression or achievement of something
any inanimate object (as a towel or money or clothing or dishes or books or toys etc.) that can transmit infectious agents from one person to another

vehicular.explanation: Of, relating to, or intended for vehicles, especially motor vehicles.
Of or pertaining to a vehicle; serving as a vehicle.
Of or pertaining to a vehicle or vehicles, usually specifically cars and trucks .
Of or pertaining to a language that is used as a contact language between two groups who do not share a common native tongue nor a common culture.
of or relating to or intended for (motor) vehicles

vehiculate.explanation: To convey by means of a vehicle; to ride in a vehicle.
To convey by means of a vehicle .

vehmic.explanation: Of, pertaining to, or designating, certain secret tribunals which flourished in Germany from the end of the 12th century to the middle of the 16th, usurping many of the functions of the governments which were too weak to maintain law and order, and inspiring dread in all who came within their jurisdiction.

veil.explanation: A length of cloth worn over the head, shoulders, and often the face, especially by women.
A length of netting attached to a woman's hat or habit, worn for decoration or to protect the head and face.
A length of protective netting worn over the face by beekeepers.
The part of a nun's headdress that frames the face and falls over the shoulders.
The life or vows of a nun.
Any of various cloth head coverings worn by Muslim women.
A piece of light fabric hung to separate or conceal what is behind it; a curtain.
Something that conceals, separates, or screens like a curtain.
A membranous covering or part, as that on the developing fruiting body of certain mushrooms; a velum.
To cover with or as if with a veil.
To conceal or disguise.
To wear a veil.
A cloth or other fabric or material intended to conceal something from the eye; a curtain.

A piece of stuff, usually very light and more or less transparent, as lawn or lace, intended to conceal, wholly or in part, the features from close observation, while not materially obstructing the vision of the wearer; hence, such a piece of stuff forming a head-dress or part of a head-dress, especially for women.
Hence, anything that prevents observation; a covering, mask, or disguise; also, a pretense.
A scarf tied to or hanging from a pastoral staff. See ovarium , 3, sudarium , vexillum , and banderole , 1 .
In anatomy and zoology , a velum.
In botany : In Hymenomycetes , same as velum , 2 .
In Discomycetes , a membranous or fibrous coating stretching over the mouth of the cup.
In mosses , same as calyptra , 1 .
In phonation , an obscuration of the clearness of the tones, either from a natural conformation of the larynx or from some accidental condition, as fatigue or a cold.
To throw a veil over; to cover with a veil.
Fig.: To invest; to cover; to hide; to conceal.
Something hung up, or spread out, to intercept the view, and hide an object; a cover; a curtain; esp., a screen, usually of gauze, crape, or similar diaphnous material, to hide or protect the face.
A cover; a disguise; a mask; a pretense.
The calyptra of mosses.
A membrane connecting the margin of the pileus of a mushroom with the stalk; -- called also velum .
A covering for a person or thing
Same as Velum , 3.
to receive or be covered with, a veil, as a nun, in token of retirement from the world; to become a nun.
Something hung up, or spread out, to intercept the view, and hide an object; a cover; a curtain; esp., a screen, usually of gauze , crape, or similar diaphanous material, to hide or protect the face.
A cover; disguise; a mask; a pretense.
The calyptra of mosses .
A membrane connecting the margin of the pileus of a mushroom with the stalk; -- called also velum.
A covering for a person or thing; as, a caul ; a nun's veil; a paten veil; an altar veil; a Moslem veil.
Same as velum , 4.
A thin layer of tissue which is attached to or covers a mushroom.
To don , or garb with, a veil.
To conceal as with a veil.
make undecipherable or imperceptible by obscuring or concealing
a vestment worn by a priest at High Mass in the Roman Catholic Church; a silk shawl
a garment that covers the head and face
to obscure, or conceal with or as if with a veil

veiled.explanation: Concealed or disguised as if with a veil.
Covered by, or as by, a veil; hidden.
Hidden , such as by a veil .
Simple past tense and past participle of veil .
having or as if having a veil or concealing cover

veiler.explanation: One who or that which veils.

veiling.explanation: Sheer material, such as gauze or fine lace, used for veils.
The act of concealing with a veil.
Material for making veils: as, nun's- veiling ; silk veiling.
A veil; a thin covering; also, material for making veils.
a net of transparent fabric with a loose open weave

veilleuse.explanation: In decorative art , a shaded night-lamp. The shade or screen in such lamps was frequently the medium for rich decoration.

veillike.explanation: Resembling a veil or some aspect of one.

vein.explanation: Any of the membranous tubes that form a branching system and carry blood to the heart from the cells, tissues, and organs of the body.
A blood vessel of any kind; a vein or artery.
One of the strands of vascular tissue that form the conducting and supporting framework in a leaf or other expanded plant organ.
One of the thickened cuticular ribs that form the supporting network of the wing of an insect and that often carry hemolymph.
A regularly shaped and lengthy occurrence of an ore; a lode.
A long wavy strip of a different shade or color, as in wood or marble, or as mold in cheese.
A fissure, crack, or cleft.
A pervading character or quality; a streak.
A transient attitude or mood.
A particular turn of mind.
To supply or fill with veins.
To mark or decorate with veins.

In anatomy , one of a set of blood-vessels conveying blood from the periphery to the physiological center of the circulation; one of a set of membranous canals or tubes distributed in nearly all the tissues and organs of the body, for the purpose of carrying blood from these parts to the heart.
Loosely, any blood-vessel.
In entomology , one of the ribs or horny tubes which form the frame work of the wings of an insect, and between which the thin membrane of the wings is spread and supported; a nervure.
In botany , a fibrovascular bundle at or near the surface of a leaf, sepal, petal, etc.: same as nerve , 7. See nervation .
In mining , an occurrence of ore. usually disseminated through a gangue or veinstone, and having a more or less regular development in length, width, and depth.
A cavity, fissure, or cleft, as in the earth or other substance.

A streak, stripe, or marking, of different color or shade, as in natural marble or wood cut so as to show the grain, or glass in which different colors have been melted irregularly. The term is applied either to a long and nearly regular stripe, or to a much broken and contorted one, returning upon itself. Also called veining .

A streak; a part of anything marked off from the rest by some distinctive character; hence, a distinct property or characteristic considered as running through or being intermingled with others; a continued strain.
Manner of speech or action; particular style, character, disposition, or cast of mind.
Particular mood, temper, humor, or disposition for the time being.
To form or mark with veins; to fill or cover with veins.
One of the vessels which carry blood, either venous or arterial, to the heart. See artery , 2.
One of the similar branches of the framework of a leaf.
One of the ribs or nervures of the wings of insects. See Venation .

A narrow mass of rock intersecting other rocks, and filling inclined or vertical fissures not corresponding with the stratification; a lode; a dike; -- often limited, in the language of miners, to a mineral vein or lode, that is, to a vein which contains useful minerals or ores.
A fissure, cleft, or cavity, as in the earth or other substance.
A streak or wave of different color, appearing in wood, and in marble and other stones; variegation.
A train of associations, thoughts, emotions, or the like; a current; a course.
Peculiar temper or temperament; tendency or turn of mind; a particular disposition or cast of genius; humor; strain; quality; also, manner of speech or action.
A blood vessel that transports blood from the capillaries back to the heart
The entrails of a shrimp
In leaves, a thickened portion of the leaf containing the vascular bundle
The nervure of an insect ’s wing
A stripe or streak of a different colour or composition in materials such as wood , cheese , marble or other rocks
A topic of discussion
A style , tendency , or quality of something
one of the horny ribs that stiffen and support the wing of an insect
make a veinlike pattern
a layer of ore between layers of rock
any of the vascular bundles or ribs that form the branching framework of conducting and supporting tissues in a leaf or other plant organ
a distinctive style or manner
a blood vessel that carries blood from the capillaries toward the heart

veinage.explanation: Veining; veins collectively; markings in the form of veins. R. D. Blackmore , Alice Lorraine, xlviii.

veinal.explanation: Alternative form of venal . (relating to veins)
relating to the veins of plants

veined.explanation: Having veins or showing veinlike markings.
botany , having veins, as a leaf; traversed by fibrovascular strands or bundles.
Having fibrovascular threads extending throughout the lamina.
having or showing markings that resemble veins

veining.explanation: Distribution or arrangement of veins or veinlike markings.
The formation or disposition of veins; venation; a venous network.
In weaving , a stripe in the cloth formed by a vacancy in the warp.
A kind of needlework in which the veins of a piece of muslin are wrought to a pattern.
An arrangement of veins or veinlike markings

veinlet.explanation: A small or secondary vein, as on the wing of an insect.
A small vein; a venous radicle uniting with another to form a vein; a venule.
In entomology , one of the secondary or lesser veins of the wings: same as nervule . See vein , n., 3.
In botany , a small vein; one of the ultimate or smaller ramifications of a vein or rib; a nerville.
A small or secondary vein , especially on the wing of an insect .

veinlike.explanation: Resembling a vein or some aspect of one.
having or showing markings that resemble veins

veinous.explanation: botany and zoology , veined; provided with veins or nerves.

veinstone.explanation: Mineral matter in a vein exclusive of the ore; gangue.
The earthy or nonmetalliferous part of a lode, vein, or ore-deposit. See gangue .
A concretion formed within a vein; a phlebolite.
The valueless nonmetalliferous mineral or rock material which surrounds the ores in a vein, as quartz, calcite, barite, fluor spar, etc.; gangue; matrix; -- called also veinstuff .

veiny.explanation: Full of or exhibiting veins; veined.

vejovis.explanation: A notable genus of scorpions, having ten eyes and a pentagonal sternum, with some authors giving name to a family Vejovidæ.

velamen.explanation: A membranous covering or partition; velum.
A spongy layer of dead cells that covers the aerial roots of most orchids and certain other plants and may serve to absorb atmospheric moisture.

velamentous.explanation: Of or relating to an abnormal condition during pregnancy in which the umbilical cord inserts into the fetal membranes , then travels within the membranes to the placenta , risking rupture of the exposed vessels .

velamentum.explanation: In anatomy and zoology , a membrane or membranous envelop; a covering, as a veil or velum.

velar.explanation: Of or relating to a velum.
Concerning or using the soft palate.
Articulated with the back of the tongue touching or near the soft palate, as (g) in good and (k) in king.
philology , noting certain sounds, as those represented by the letters gw, kw, qu , produced by the aid of the veil of the palate, or soft palate.
Of or pertaining to a velum; esp. (Anat.) of or pertaining to the soft palate.
Having the place of articulation on the soft palate; guttural.
Articulated at the velum or soft palate .
a sound articulated at the soft palate
of or relating to the velum
a consonant produced with the back of the tongue touching or near the soft palate
produced with the back of the tongue touching or near the soft palate (as `k' in `cat' and `g' in `gun' and `ng' in `sing')

velaric.explanation: Produced by combining a closure at the velum and a lowering of the tongue to decrease the pressure in the mouth .

velarium.explanation: A large awning, especially one suspended over a Roman theater or amphitheater.
An awning which was often drawn over the roofless Roman theaters and amphitheaters to protect the spectators from rain or the sun. Also velum .
[NL.] In zoology , the marginal membrane of certain hydrozoans; the velum. See velum , 4.
The marginal membrane of certain medusæ belonging to the Discophora.
The marginal membrane of certain medusae belonging to the Discophora.

velarization.explanation: The act or process of velarizing .

velarize.explanation: To articulate (a sound) by retracting the back of the tongue toward the soft palate.
to raise the back of the tongue toward the velum while articulating another consonant.

velarized.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of velarize .

velarizes.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of velarize .

velate.explanation: Having or covered by a velum or veil.
zoology and hot. , having a velum.

velation.explanation: A veiling; the act of covering or the state of being covered with or as with a veil; hence, concealment; mystery; secrecy: the opposite of revelation .

velatura.explanation: In the fine arts , the art or process of glazing a picture by rubbing on a thin covering of color with the hand. It was a device much practised by early Italian painters.

veld.explanation: Any of the open grazing areas of southern Africa.
The open pasture land of South Africa.
elevated open grassland in southern Africa

veldskoen.explanation: A shoe with untanned leather upper sewn without nails, similar to the Canadian moccasin . Thought to have been made by the Khoe people (known perjoratively as Hottentots ) before the arrival of Europeans , but still made and worn in South Africa.

veldt.explanation: In South Africa, an unforested or thinly forested tract of land or region; grass country.
A region or tract of land; esp., the open field, thinly forested or with bushes and shrubs; grass country.
elevated open grassland in southern Africa

velella.explanation: [ lowercase ] A member of this genus.
Any species of oceanic Siphonophora belonging to the genus Velella.
Any of the genus Velella of free-floating marine protozoans .

veliferous.explanation: zoology , having a velum; velate; veligerous; velamentous.

veliger.explanation: A larval mollusk that is free-swimming and has a velum.

One who or that which bears a velum; in Mollusca , specifically, the veligerous stage of the embryo, or the embryo in that stage, when it has a ciliated swimmingmembrane or velum (see velum , 3, and typembryo ).
Any larval gastropod or bivalve mollusk in the stage when it is furnished with one or two ciliated membranes for swimming.
The planktonic larva of many kinds of marine and freshwater gastropod molluscs , as well as most bivalve molluscs.

veligerous.explanation: zoology , bearing a velum; veliferous: specifically noting an embryonic stage of mollusks. See velum , 3, and cut under veliger .

vell.explanation: The salted stomach of a calf, used in making cheese; a rennet bag.
To cut the turf from, as for burning.
To cut the turf from, as for burning .

velleity.explanation: A slight or weak wish or inclination.
Volition in the weakest form; an indolent or inactive wish or inclination toward a thing, which leads to no energetic effort to obtain it: chiefly a scholastic term.
The lowest degree of desire; imperfect or incomplete volition.
The lowest degree of desire or volition , with no effort to act.
A slight wish not followed by any effort to obtain.
a mere wish, unaccompanied by effort to obtain

vellicate.explanation: To twitch; to cause to twitch convulsively.
to touch (a body part ) lightly so as to excite the surface nerves and cause uneasiness , laughter , or spasmodic movements
to irritate as if by a nip , pinch , or tear
irritate as if by a nip, pinch, or tear
touch (a body part) lightly so as to excite the surface nerves and cause uneasiness, laughter, or spasmodic movements

vellicated.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of vellicate .

vellication.explanation: The act of twitching or of causing to twitch.
A twitching or convulsive motion of a muscular fiber. Compare subsultus .
a sudden muscle spasm; especially one caused by a nervous condition

vellicative.explanation: Having the power of vellicating, plucking, or twitching; causing vellication.
Having the power of vellicating, plucking, or twitching; causing vellication .

vellon.explanation: A Spanish money of account. The term is also used like the English word sterling. The reale de vellon is worth about 4½ cents.
A word occurring in the phrase real vellon. See the Note under 1st real .

vellosine.explanation: A colorless, dextrorotatory, poisonous alkaloid, C 21 H 22 O 2 N 2 (OCH 3 ) 2 , contained in Brazilian pereira-bark, Geissospermum Vellosii. It crystallizes in trimetric plates, melts and darkens at 189° C., and resembles brucine in general physiological effect.

vellozia.explanation: A genus of monocotyledonous plants, of the order Amaryllidaceæ , type of the tribe Vellozieæ , and distinguished from Barbacenia , the other genus of that tribe, by a perianth-tube not prolonged above the ovary.

vellum.explanation: A fine parchment made from calfskin, lambskin, or kidskin and used for the pages and binding of books.
A work written or printed on this parchment.
A heavy off-white fine-quality paper resembling this parchment.
The skin of calves prepared for writing, printing, or painting by long exposure in a bath of lime and by repeated rubbings with a burnisher; also, the skin of goats or kids similarly prepared.
A fine kind of parchment, usually made from calfskin, and rendered clear and white, -- used as for writing upon, and for binding books.
a fine kind of cotton fabric, made very transparent, and used as a tracing cloth.
A type of parchment paper made from the skin of a lamb , baby goat, or calf .
A writing paper of very high quality.
fine parchment prepared from the skin of a young animal e.g. a calf or lamb
a heavy creamy-colored paper resembling parchment

velo.explanation: In physics , a proposed unit of linear velocity; a velocity of one foot per second of time.

veloce.explanation: Rapidly. Used chiefly as a direction.

velociman.explanation: A vehicle of the nature of a velocipede, driven by hand.

velocimeter.explanation: A device for measuring the speed of sound in water.
An apparatus for measuring velocity or speed.
Specifically, an instrument for measuring the initial velocity of a projectile.
An apparatus for measuring speed, as of machinery or vessels, but especially of projectiles.
A device used to measure the speed of sound in a liquid

velocipede.explanation: Any of several early bicycles having pedals attached to the front wheel.
An early bicycle propelled by pushing the feet along the ground while straddling the vehicle.
An electric jib-crane which runs on a single track and is held upright by the post running between two rails at the top.
A light vehicle or carriage, with two wheels or three, impelled by the rider.

A light road carriage propelled by the feet of the rider. Originally it was propelled by striking the tips of the toes on the roadway, but commonly now by the action of the feet on a pedal or pedals connected with the axle of one or more of the wheels, and causing their revolution. They are made in many forms, with two, three, or four wheels. See bicycle , and tricycle .
Early two-wheeled conveyance upon which one rode astride a wooden frame propelled by means of pushing the feet against the ground
Generic term for three and four-wheeled machines driven by foot or hand levers to the rear or front axle
a late-1860s bicycle driven by cranks on the front axle
any of several early bicycles with pedals on the front wheel
a vehicle with three wheels that is moved by foot pedals

velocity.explanation: Rapidity or speed of motion; swiftness.
A vector quantity whose magnitude is a body's speed and whose direction is the body's direction of motion.
The rate of speed of action or occurrence.
The rate at which money changes hands in an economy.
Quickness of motion; speed in movement; swiftness; rapidity; celerity: used only (or chiefly) of inanimate objects. See def. 2.
.2. In physics , rate of motion; the rate at which a body changes its position in space; the rate of change of position of a point per unit of time.
In music , decided rapidity of tempo or pace, particularly in a bravura passage.
The velocity at which the mode of flow of a liquid, in a pipe or channel, is modified by the setting up of eddy-motion and the consequent interruption of the stream lines.
Same as critical velocity .
The velocity of a given individual wave-length of light as opposed to the group velocity of a complex beam taken as a whole.
Quickness of motion; swiftness; speed; celerity; rapidity

Rate of motion; the relation of motion to time, measured by the number of units of space passed over by a moving body or point in a unit of time, usually the number of feet passed over in a second. See the Note under Speed .
See under Angular .
the velocity of a moving body at starting; especially, the velocity of a projectile as it leaves the mouth of a firearm from which it is discharged.
the velocity with which a body approaches or recedes from another body, whether both are moving or only one.
velocity in which the same number of units of space are described in each successive unit of time.

velocity in which the space described varies from instant to instant, either increasing or decreasing; -- in the former case called accelerated velocity , in the latter, retarded velocity ; the acceleration or retardation itself being also either uniform or variable .
See under Virtual .
A vector quantity that denotes the rate of change of position with respect to time, or a speed with the directional component.
Rapidity of motion.
The rate of occurrence.
The number of times that an average unit of currency is spent during a specific period of time.
distance travelled per unit time

velodrome.explanation: A sports arena with a banked oval track for bicycle and motorcycle racing.
A race-course for bicycles and the like.
A hollow cone (or frustum of a cone) of thin boards or slats, within which a bicycle-rider exhibits feats of riding and dynamic support of the weight of wheel and rider.
An indoor arena , having an oval banked track for bicycle racing .
a banked oval track for bicycle or motorcycle racing

velometer.explanation: An instrument that measures the speed of air .

velour.explanation: A closely napped fabric resembling velvet, used chiefly for clothing and upholstery.
A felt resembling velvet, used in making hats.
A knit fabric similar to velvet , but usually somewhat coarser .

velours.explanation: Same as velure : the more common form in trade use.
One of many textile fabrics having a pile like that of velvet.

veloutine.explanation: A French corded fabric of merino and fancy wool.

velum.explanation: A covering or partition of thin membranous tissue, such as the veil of a mushroom, a rim of tissue around the margin of the bell of certain cnidarians, or a membrane of the brain.
The soft palate.
A ciliated swimming and feeding organ that develops in certain larval stages of most gastropod and bivalve mollusks.
[ capitalized ] One of the subdivisions of the constellation Argo Navis. See Argo , 2.
Same as velarium , 1.
In botany : In Hymenomycetes , a special membranous envelop which incloses for a time the whole or a part of the sporophore.
In Isoëtes , the outgrown membranous margin of the fovea. Also called involucrum .

In Mollusca , the highly characteristic ciliated formation of the embryo, which serves as an organ of locomotion in that stage when the embryo is called a veliger. It is usually soon lost, but in some cases is permanently retained in a modified form. See cuts under veliger .

In Hydrozoa , a kind of flap or circular free edge which projects inward around the margin of the disk of many hydrozoans, as those which are bell-shaped or conical, and which from its presence are called craspedote; a velarium.

vena.explanation: In anatomy , a vein. See vein

The superior or descending vena cava returns the blood from the head and neck, the upper limbs, and the whole of the thorax. It is formed by the junction of the right and left innominate veins, behind the junction of the first costal cartilage of the right side with the sternum, and descends nearly vertically to empty into the right auricle of the heart. It receives the pericardial and mediastinal veins and the large azygous vein. In vertebrates at large the two venæ cavæ are distinguished as postcaval and precaval veins. See cuts under circulation, diaphragm, embryo, heart, lung, pancreas , and thorax.

venal.explanation: Characterized by corrupt dealings, especially bribery.

Venal, Mercenary, Hireling. These words represent a person or thing as ready to be dishonorably employed for pay. Each is strongest in one sense. Venal is strongest in expressing the idea of complete sale to a purchaser—character, honor, principle, and even individuality being surrendered for value received, the venal man doing whatever his purchaser directs, a venal press advocating whatever it is told to advocate. Mercenary is strongest in expressing rapacity, or greed for gain, and activity. Hireling is strongest in expressing servility and consequent contempt, hire having become an ignoble word for pay: as, a hireling soldiery; a hireling defamer. A venal man sells his political or other support; mercenary man sells his work, being chiefly anxious to get as much pay as possible; a hireling will do mean or base work as long as he is sure of his pay. Venal means a being ready to sell one's principles, whether he makes out to sell them or not; mercenary and hireling suggest more of actual employment.
Of or pertaining to veins; venous.
Capable of being bought or obtained for money or other valuable consideration; made matter of trade or barter; held for sale; salable; mercenary; purchasable; hireling.

Excusable and pardonable are applied to things small and great, but pardonable primarily applies to greater offenses, as pardoning is a more serious act than excusing. Excusable may be applied where the offense is only in seeming. Venial applies to things actually done; the others may apply to infirmities and the like. These serpents constitute two tribes, the viperine serpents, or Solenoglypha, and the cobralike serpents, or Proteroglypha. The former have perforated, erectile fangs situated in the front part of the upper jaw, and are without ordinary teeth behind the fangs; the latter have permanently erect and grooved fangs, with ordinary maxillary teeth behind them.

veratrine.explanation: A poisonous mixture of alkaloids extracted from sabadilla seeds and used as an insecticide and formerly as a counterirritant.

A poisonous alkaloid obtained from the root of hellebore (Veratrum) and from sabadilla seeds as a white crystalline powder, having an acrid, burning taste. It is sometimes used externally, as in ointments, in the local treatment of neuralgia and rheumatism. Called also veratria , and veratrina .
A poisonous mixture of alkaloids ( veratridines ) obtained from the seeds of the sabadilla plant

veratroidine.explanation: An alkaloid, supposed to be identical with rubijervine, obtained from Veratrum viride .

veratrol.explanation: A colorless, crystalline compound, C 6 H 4 (OCH 3 ) 2 , prepared by heating barium veratrate. It melts at 15° C. and boils at 205–206° C. Also called pyrocatechol dimethyl ether or 1,2- dimeth-oxybenzene.
A liquid hydrocarbon obtained by the decomposition of veratric acid, and constituting the dimethyl ether of pyrocatechin.
A liquid hydrocarbon obtained by the decomposition of veratric acid, and constituting the dimethyl ether of pyrocatechin .

veratrole.explanation: The compound 1,2-dimethoxybenzene, a dimethyl ether derived from pyrocatechol .

veratrum.explanation: A genus of liliaceous plants, type of the tribe Veratreæ.
A genus of coarse liliaceous herbs having very poisonous qualities.
Any of various poisonous herbs of the genus Veratrum
a genus of coarse poisonous perennial herbs; sometimes placed in subfamily Melanthiaceae

veray.explanation: A Middle English form of very .

verb.explanation: The part of speech that expresses existence, action, or occurrence in most languages.

In grammar , a word that asserts or declares; that part of speech of which the office is predication, and which, either alone or with various modifiers or adjuncts, combines with a subject to make a sentence.
A word which affirms or predicates something of some person or thing; a part of speech expressing being, action, or the suffering of action.
etc. See Active , Auxiliary , Neuter , etc.
A word that indicates an action, event, or state.
To use any word that is not a verb (especially a noun) as if it were a verb.
To perform any action that is normally expressed by a verb.

a content word that denotes an action, occurrence, or state of existence

Concerned with words only rather than with content or ideas.

Having word answering to word; word for word; literal.
Abounding with words; verbose.

a noun derived directly from a verb or verb stem; a verbal. The term is specifically applied to infinitives, and nouns ending in -ing , esp. to the latter. See Gerund , and -ing , 2. See also, Infinitive mood, under Infinitive .

Concerned with the words, rather than the substance of a text .

Expressly spoken or written .
Derived from, or having the nature of a verb .
Used to form a verb.

In English forest law , a judicial officer in the royal forests, whose peculiar charge was to take care of the vert—that is, the trees and underwood of the forest—and to keep the assizes, as well as to view, receive, and enroll attachments and presentments of all manner of trespasses.
An officer who has the charge of the king's forest, to preserve the vert and venison, keep the assizes, view, receive, and enroll attachments and presentments of all manner of trespasses.

a pale greenish blue color, like that of the pigment verditer.

The quality or state of being verisimilar; the appearance of truth; probability; likelihood.
the property of seeming true , of resembling reality; resemblance to reality, realism
a statement which merely appears to be true
the appearance of truth; the quality of seeming to be true

verisimilitudinous.explanation: appearing to be verisimilar ; exhibiting verisimilitude , in either a neutral or a dubious sense.

verism.explanation: Presenting common , everyday subjects, specifically eschewing the heroic or legendary .
A movement in the late 19th century, related to realism

verismo.explanation: An artistic movement of the late 1800s, originating in Italy and influential especially in grand opera, marked by the use of rural characters and common, everyday themes often treated in a melodramatic manner.
An artistic movement , from 19th century Italian literature and opera , in which rural and everyday people and themes were treated in an often melodramatic manner

veritable.explanation: Being truly so called; real or genuine.
Agreeable to truth or to fact; actual; real; true; genuine.

veritably.explanation: In a veritable manner; in a way that truly and accurately describes something.

veritas.explanation: A name given to a register of shipping in France on the principle of Lloyd's. The name has also been used for the same purpose in Norway and in Austria.
The Bureau Veritas. See under bureau .
Truth, particularly of a transcendent character

veritism.explanation: The methods or work of the veritists. See veritist .

veritist.explanation: A recent name for a form of realism which takes pleasure in portraying what is debased or abnormal.

verity.explanation: The quality or condition of being true, factual, or real.
Something, such as a statement or principle, that is true, especially an enduring truth. synonym : truth .
The quality of being true or real; true or real nature or principle; reality; truth; fact.
That which is true; a true assertion or tenet; a truth; a reality; a fact.
Honesty; faith; trustworthiness.
that the cause of suffering is desire or a craving for existence and its pleasures
that deliverance from suffering can be effected only by the eradication of desire
and that this can be accomplished only by walking in the noble eightfold path of right views in regard to life
of right aims
of right words
of right conduct
of right means of livelihood (celibate mendicancy)
of right effort
of right-mindfulness (that is, freedom from error in recollecting the law)
and of right meditation and tranquillity. See nidana .
The quality or state of being true, or real; consonance of a statement, proposition, or other thing, with fact; truth; reality.
That which is true; a true assertion or tenet; a truth; a reality.
Truth , fact or reality , especially an enduring religious or ethical truth.
A true statement; an established doctrine .
conformity to reality or actuality
an enduring or necessary ethical or religious or aesthetic truth

verjuice.explanation: The acidic juice of unripe grapes or other sour fruit, such as crabapples.
An acid liquor expressed from crab-apples, unripe grapes, etc., used for culinary and other purposes.
Sourness or acidity of temper, manner, or expression; tartness.
The sour juice of crab apples, of green or unripe grapes, apples, etc.; also, an acid liquor made from such juice.
A very acidic juice made by pressing unripe grapes .

vermeil.explanation: Vermilion or a similar bright red color.
A bright red; vermilion; the color of vermilion. Also used adjeetively, and frequently as the first element of a compound.
In gilding , a liquid composed of arnotto, gamboge, vermilion, dragon's-blood, salt of tartar, and saffron, boiled in water and applied to a surface that is to be gilded, to give luster to the gold.
A crimson-red garnet inclining slightly to orange: a jewelers' name.
Vermilion; also, the color of vermilion, a bright, beautiful red.
A liquid composition applied to a gilded surface to give luster to the gold.
Specifically of faces , lips etc.: red , ruddy , healthy-looking.
A liquid composition applied to a gilded surface to give luster to the gold.

vermeologist.explanation: One who is versed in vermeology; a helminthologist.
One who treats of vermes, or worms; a helminthologist.

vermeology.explanation: The knowledge or description of worms; that branch of zoölogy which treats of the Vermes ; helminthology.
A discourse or treatise on worms; that part of zoölogy which treats of worms; helminthology.

vermes.explanation: Mammalia, Aves, Amphibia, Pisces , and Insecta (or vertebrates and insects).

Metazoa ), no backbone ( Invertebrata ), normally an intestinal canal (which Cœlentera have not), not a radiate structure (which Echinodermata have), legs if any not jointed (they are always jointed in Arthropoda ), and body vermiform if there are no legs.

An extensive artificial division of the animal kingdom, including the parasitic worms, or helminths, together with the nemerteans, annelids, and allied groups. By some writers the branchiopods, the bryzoans, and the tunicates are also included. The name was used in a still wider sense by Linnæus and his followers.
A more restricted group, comprising only the helminths and closely allied orders.

vermetus.explanation: The typical genus of Vermetidæ , having the later whorls of the shell separated and crooked or tortuous.

Any one of many species of marine gastropods belonging to Vermetus and allied genera, of the family Vermetidæ . Their shells are regularly spiral when young, but later in life the whorls become separate, and the shell is often irregularly bent and contorted like a worm tube.
Any of many species of marine gastropods belonging to Vermetus and allied genera , of the family Vermetidae.

vermian.explanation: anatomy , relating to the vermis of the cerebellum.
Vermes , in any sense: as, the supposed vermian ancestors of vertebrates.

vermicelli.explanation: Pasta in long, very thin strands.
An Italian paste prepared of flour, cheese, yolks of eggs, sugar, and saffron, manufactured in the form of long slender threads, and so named on account of its wormlike appearance.

The flour of a hard and small-grained wheat made into dough, and forced through small cylinders or pipes till it takes a slender, wormlike form, whence the Italian name. When the paste is made in larger tubes, it is called macaroni .
long, slender pasta , similar to spaghetti , only thicker.
pasta in strings thinner than spaghetti

vermicidal.explanation: Serving to kill worms , as a vermicide .

vermicide.explanation: A substance or agent used to kill worms, especially parasitic worms.
A worm-killer; that which destroys worms: applied to those anthelmintic drugs which act by killing, and not simply expelling, parasitic worms, such as entozoans.
A medicine which destroys intestinal worms; a worm killer.
Any substance used to kill worms , especially parasitic intestinal worms
an agent that kills worms (especially those in the intestines)

vermicious.explanation: Of or pertaining to worms; wormy.
Of, pertaining to, or characteristic of worms .

vermicular.explanation: Having the shape of a worm; vermiform.
Having wavy markings shaped like worms; vermiculate.
Caused by or relating to worms.
botany , shaped like a worm; thick, and almost cylindrical, but bent in different places, as some roots
Of or pertaining to a worm or worms; resembling a worm; shaped like a worm; especially, resembling the motion or track of a worm. See peristaltic .
Of, pertaining to, or having the form of a worm ; vermiculate
decorated with wormlike tracery or markings

vermicularia.explanation: A large genus of Fungi Imperfecti , having mostly superficial, black, membranous pycnidia provided with stiff dark bristles.

vermiculate.explanation: To adorn or decorate with wavy or winding lines.
Having a wormlike motion; twisting or wriggling.
: Forming a vermiculation; fine, close-set, and wavy or tortuous, as color-marks; vermicular: as, vermiculate color-markings.
To form or work, as by inlaying, with irregular lines or impressions resembling the tracks of worms, or appearing as if formed by the motion of worms.
Wormlike in shape; covered with wormlike elevations; marked with irregular fine lines of color, or with irregular wavy impressed lines like worm tracks.
Crawling or creeping like a worm; hence, insinuating; sophistical.
to decorate with lines resembling the tracks of worms
Like a worm ; resembling a worm .
infested with or damaged (as if eaten) by worms
decorate with wavy or winding lines
decorated with wormlike tracery or markings

vermiculated.explanation: Made or marked with irregular wavy lines or impressions; vermiculate.
rustic work so wrought as to have the appearance of convoluted worms, or of having been eaten into by, or covered with tracks of, worms.
Simple past tense and past participle of vermiculate .
Decorated with lines like worm tracks.
decorated with wormlike tracery or markings

vermiculation.explanation: Motion resembling that of a worm, especially the wavelike contractions of the intestine; peristalsis.
Wavy or sinuous marks or ornamentation, as in a mosaic, masonry, or the plumage of a bird.
A color-marking of fine, wavy lines: a term frequently used in describing the plumage of birds.
The action or movement of a worm; hence, a continuous or progressive motion along the bowels, which is strikingly like the action of successive joints of a worm in crawling; peristaltic action.
Formation of worm-like figures or tracery; vermicular ornamentation, whether of form or of color; a set or system of vermiculate lines. See cuts under rustic and vermicular.
The act or art of producing vermiculated ornament.
Worminess; the state of being wormy or worm-eaten, literally or figuratively.
The act or operation of moving in the manner of a worm; continuation of motion from one part to another.
The act of vermiculating, or forming or inlaying so as to resemble the motion, track, or work of a worm.
Penetration by worms; the state of being wormeaten.
A very fine wavy crosswise color marking, or a patch of such markings, as on the feathers of birds.
A pattern of irregular wavy lines.
the process of wavelike muscle contractions of the alimentary tract that moves food along
a decoration consisting of wormlike carvings

vermicule.explanation: A motile, worm-like stage in the development of some sporozoans. See pseudorermiculus .
A little worm or grub; a small wormlike body or object. Also, rarely, vermicle.
A small worm or insect larva; also, a wormlike body.
A small worm or insect larva.

vermiculite.explanation: Any of a group of micaceous hydrated silicate minerals related to the chlorites and used in heat-expanded form as insulation and as a planting medium.
In mineralogy , one of a group of hydrous silicates having a micaceous structure, and in most cases derived from the common micas by alteration.

A group of minerals having, a micaceous structure. They are hydrous silicates, derived generally from the alteration of some kind of mica. So called because the scales, when heated, open out into wormlike forms.
A hydrated silicate mineral which expands on heating; it is used in insulation and as a medium for planting
any of a group of yellow or brown hydrous silicate minerals having a micaceous structure

vermiculose.explanation: Containing, or full of, worms; resembling worms.

vermiculous.explanation: Containing, or full of, worms ; resembling worms; wormy .

vermiform.explanation: Having the shape of a worm.
Vermes; vermian; helminthic; annuloid or annulose.

entomology : Noting any maggot or maggot like larva, as those of most Hymenoptera and Diptera. Noting certain worm-like polyphagous larvæ;, with only rudimentary antennæ, and apodous or with very short legs like tubercles, as those of most weevils and longicorns.
Resembling a worm in form or motions; vermicular.

a slender blind process of the cæcum in man and some other animals; -- called also vermiform appendage , and vermiform process . Small solid bodies, such as grape seeds or cherry stones, sometimes lodge in it, causing serious, or even fatal, inflammation. See Illust. under Digestion .
In the shape of a worm .
resembling a worm; long and thin and cylindrical

vermiformia.explanation: Podaxonia , containing only the genus Phoronis.
A tribe of worms including Phoronis. See phoronis .

vermifugal.explanation: Tending to prevent, destroy, or expel, worms or vermin; anthelmintic.
Tending to prevent, destroy, or expel worms or vermin ; anthelmintic .

vermifuge.explanation: A medicine that expels intestinal worms.
Causing expulsion of intestinal worms; anthelmintic.
A remedy employed to effect the dislodgment and expulsion of intestinal worms.
A medicine or substance that expels worms from animal bodies; an anthelmintic.
Referring to something that acts as a drug to cause expulsion or death of intestinal worms.
A drug that causes the expulsion or death of intestinal worms, such as tapeworms.
a medication capable of causing the evacuation of parasitic intestinal worms

vermilinguia.explanation: Cingulata ), both these being families of his ninth order, Effodientia : now restricted to the American ant-eaters, as a subordinal group. See cuts under ant-bear and tamandua.
herpetology , a superfamily of lizards, including only the chameleons; the Dendrosaura or Rhiptogiossa. Also Vermilingues . See cut under chameleon .
A tribe of edentates comprising the South American ant-eaters. The tongue is long, slender, exsertile, and very flexible, whence the name.
A tribe of Old World lizards which comprises the chameleon. They have long, flexible tongues.

vermilinguial.explanation: ornithology , same as sagittilingual . See cut under sagittilingual .

vermilion.explanation: A vivid red to reddish orange.
Of a vivid red to reddish orange.
To color or dye (something) in the hue vermilion.
The kermes- or cochineal-insect; also, the product of cochineal; worm-dye.

The red sulphid of mercury, or the mineral cinnabar, occurring in nature of a red-brown to a carmine-red color; also, a pigment formerly made by grinding selected pieces of native cinnabar, but now made artificially.
A color such as that of the above pigment; a beautiful brilliant red color.
A cotton cloth dyed with vermilion.
Same as vermeil , 4.
vermilion dye.
To color with vermilion, or as if with vermilion; to dye red; to cover with a delicate red.
A bright red pigment consisting of mercuric sulphide, obtained either from the mineral cinnabar or artificially. It has a fine red color, and is much used in coloring sealing wax, in printing, etc.
Hence, a red color like the pigment; a lively and brilliant red.
A vivid red synthetic pigment made of mercury sulfide.
A vivid red or slightly orange colour .
A type of red dye worn in the parting of the hair by married Hindu women.
A red skin of the lip or its border with the skin of the face.
Having a brilliant red colour.
Having the color of the vermilion dye.
To color or paint vermilion.
color vermilion
a variable color that is vivid red but sometimes with an orange tinge
of a vivid red to reddish-orange color

vermilionette.explanation: A trade-name for a red pigment made by precipitating a solution of eosin with sodium carbonate in water by means of lead acetate. The precipitation may be effected in the presence of red lead or basic lead chromate, or white zinc may be used as the material on which to fix the eosin. Any such product is of little value because of its fugitive character as a pigment.

vermillion.explanation: A reddish - orange pigment , mercuric sulfide (HgS), originally derived from cinnabar .
The red skin of the lip or its border with the skin of the face.
of a vivid red to reddish-orange color

vermin.explanation: Various small animals, such as rats or cockroaches, that are destructive, annoying, or injurious to health.
Animals that prey on farm animals or game or that destroy crops.
Any noxious or troublesome animal: mostly used in a collective sense.

A noxious or disgusting insect, especially a parasite; particularly, a louse, a bedbug, or a flea, A mammal or bird injurious to game, aud mischievous or troublesome in game-preserves: chiefly an English usage. Such quadrupeds as badgers, otters, weasels, polecats, rats, and mice, and such birds as hawks and owls, are all called vermin .
Hence A contemptible or obnoxious person; a low or vile fellow; also, such persons collectively.
A noxious or mischievous animal; especially, noxious little animals or insects, collectively, as squirrels, rats, mice, worms, flies, lice, bugs, etc.
Hence, in contempt, noxious human beings.
Animals that prey on game, such as foxes or weasels.
any of various small animals or insects that are pests; e.g. cockroaches or rats

verminated.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of verminate .

vermination.explanation: The generation or breeding of worms or other parasites; parasitic infestation, as by intestinal worms; helminthiasis; phthiriasis; the lousy disease
The generation or breeding of vermin.
The generation or breeding of vermin .

verminous.explanation: Of, relating to, or caused by vermin.
Tending to breed vermin; infested by vermin.
Caused by, or arising from the presence of, vermin.
Actively unpleasant , contemptible , or otherwise reminiscent of vermin.
of the nature of vermin; very offensive or repulsive

vermiphobia.explanation: An abnormal or irrational fear of worms or being infected by worms.

vermis.explanation: The region of the cerebellum lying between and connecting the two hemispheres.
In anatomy , the median lobe or division of the cerebellum; the vermiform process of the cerebellum, divided into prevermis and postvermis.

A narrow, worm -like structure found in animal brains between the hemispheres of the cerebellum ; it is the site of termination of the spinocerebellar pathways that carry subconscious proprioception .
the narrow central part of the cerebellum between the two hemispheres

vermonter.explanation: A native or an inhabitant of Vermont, one of the New England States of the United States of America.
a native or resident of Vermont

vermouth.explanation: A sweet or dry fortified wine flavored with aromatic herbs and used chiefly in mixed drinks.
A dry, or sweet apéritif wine flavored with aromatic herbs, and often used in mixed drinks.
An aperitif wine that matches the general description of vermouth.
any of several white wines flavored with aromatic herbs; used as aperitifs or in mixed drinks

vermuth.explanation: A sort of mild cordial consisting of white wine flavored with wormwood and other ingredients.
A liqueur made of white wine, absinthe, and various aromatic drugs, used to excite the appetite.

vernacle.explanation: A vernacular word, term, or expression.
A Middle English form of vernicle .

vernacular.explanation: The everyday language spoken by a people as distinguished from the literary language.
A variety of such everyday language specific to a social group or region.
The specialized vocabulary of a particular trade, profession, or group.
The common, nonscientific name of a plant or animal.
Native to or commonly spoken by the members of a particular country or region.
Using the native language of a region, especially as distinct from the literary language.
Relating to or expressed in the native language or dialect.
Of or being an indigenous building style using local materials and traditional methods of construction and ornament, especially as distinguished from academic or historical architectural styles.
Occurring or existing in a particular locality; endemic.
Relating to or designating the common, nonscientific name of a biological species.
vernacular language. The word is always, or almost always, used of the native language or ordinary idiom of a place.
vernacular architecture.
One's mother-tongue; the native idiom of a place; by extension, the language of a particular calling.
The vernacular language; one's mother tongue; often, the common forms of expression in a particular locality, opposed to literary or learned forms.
Belonging to the country of one's birth; one's own by birth or nature; native; indigenous; -- now used chiefly of language.
The language of a people, a national language.
Everyday speech , including colloquialisms , as opposed to literary or liturgical language.
Language unique to a particular group of people; jargon , argot .
The indigenous language of a people, into which the words of the Mass are translated.
Of or pertaining to everyday language .
a characteristic language of a particular group (as among thieves)
being or characteristic of or appropriate to everyday language
the everyday speech of the people (as distinguished from literary language)

vernacularism.explanation: The use of the vernacular: the opposite of classicalism .

vernacularization.explanation: The act or process of making vernacular; the state of being made vernacular.
The act or process of making vernacular, or the state of being made vernacular.
The act or process of making vernacular .

vernacularize.explanation: To translate into the everyday language spoken by a people.

vernacularly.explanation: In a vernacular manner; in the vernacular.

vernage.explanation: A kind of sweet wine from Italy.

vernal.explanation: Of, relating to, or occurring in the spring.
The trade-name of diethylmalonvlurea, a colorless, crystalline powder, used in medicine as a soporific.
botany , appearing in spring: as, vernal flowers.
vernal migration or molt of birds
Of or pertaining to the spring; appearing in the spring.
Fig.: Belonging to youth, the spring of life.
the point of time in each year when the sun crosses the equator when proceeding northward, about March 21, when day and night are of approximately equal duration. The beginning of the Spring season.

a low, soft grass ( Anthoxanthum odoratum ), producing in the spring narrow spikelike panicles, and noted for the delicious fragrance which it gives to new-mown hay; -- also called sweet vernal grass . See Illust. in Appendix.
the signs, Aries, Taurus, and Gemini, in which the sun appears between the vernal equinox and summer solstice.
suggestive of youth; vigorous and fresh
of or characteristic of or occurring in spring

vernalization.explanation: The induction of flowering by prolonged exposure to low temperatures, as during the winter in a temperate climate.
The exposure of seeds or plants to low temperatures in order to induce or hasten flowering.
The treatment of seeds or bulbs by exposure to low temperatures so as to decrease the vegetative period or to cause the plant to flower or bear fruit more quickly.

vernalized.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of vernalize .

vernalizes.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of vernalize .

vernation.explanation: The arrangement of the young leaves within a bud.
In botany , the disposition of the nascent leaves within the bud, not with reference to their insertion, but with regard to their folding, coiling, etc., taken singly or together.
The arrangement of the leaves within the leaf bud, as regards their folding, coiling, rolling, etc.; prefoliation.
The arrangement of multiple organs (such as leaves and flower parts) within a bud .
Arrangement of only leaves within the bud; prefoliation .
(botany) the arrangement of young leaves in a leaf bud before it opens

vernicle.explanation: A handkerchief impressed with the face of Christ: same as veronica , 1.

vernicose.explanation: botany , having a shiny surface as though freshly varnished.
Having a brilliantly polished surface, as some leaves.
Having a brilliantly polished surface, as some leaves do.

vernier.explanation: A small, movable auxiliary graduated scale attached parallel to a main graduated scale, calibrated to indicate fractional parts of the subdivisions of the larger scale, and used on certain precision instruments to increase accuracy in measurement.
An auxiliary device designed to facilitate fine adjustments or measurements on precision instruments.
Of, relating to, or having a vernier.

A small movable scale, running parallel with the fixed scale of a sextant. theodolite, barometer, or other graduated instrument, and used for measuring a fractional part of one of the equal divisions on the graduated fixed scale or arc.

A short scale made to slide along the divisions of a graduated instrument, as the limb of a sextant, or the scale of a barometer, for indicating parts of divisions. It is so graduated that a certain convenient number of its divisions are just equal to a certain number, either one less or one more, of the divisions of the instrument, so that parts of a division are determined by observing what line on the vernier coincides with a line on the instrument.
a gauge with a graduated bar and a sliding jaw bearing a vernier, used for accurate measurements.
a surveyor's compass with a vernier for the accurate adjustment of the zero point in accordance with magnetic variation.
a surveyor's transit instrument with a vernier compass.
A secondary scale with finer graduations than the primary scale of a measuring device; the vernier measures between graduations of the larger scale.
A secondary control input with finer control than the primary, or coarse, input; for example the vernier frequency tuning knob on a radio.
A secondary system of force application for the attitude control of a spacecraft; for example a vernier thruster.
a small movable scale that slides along a main scale; the small scale is calibrated to indicate fractional divisions of the main scale
French mathematician who described the vernier scale (1580-1637)

vernility.explanation: The character or state of being vernile; servility.

vernin.explanation: A colorless alkaloid, C 16 H 20 O 8 N 8 .3H 2 O, contained in the young shoots of the vetch, the clover, and the gourd, in hazel and pine pollen, in germinated barley, and in the sugar-beet. It crystallizes in slender, lustrous, microscopic prisms.

vernine.explanation: An alkaloid extracted from the shoots of the vetch, red clover, etc., as a white crystalline substance.
An alkaloid extracted from the shoots of the vetch , red clover , etc., as a white crystalline substance.

vernissage.explanation: A private showing held before the opening of an art exhibition.
A private viewing of an art exhibition before it opens to the public.

vernix.explanation: A waxy white protective substance consisting of desquamated epithelial cells and sebaceous matter that covers the skin of a fetus.
In medicine , used in the phrase vernix caseosa , a fatty matter covering the skin of the fetus.
Vernix caseosa ; a fatty deposit covering the skin of newborn babies.
a white cheeselike protective material that covers the skin of a fetus

vernonia.explanation: A genus of composite plants, type of the tribe Vernoniaceæ and Subtribe Euvernonieæ.

any of various plants of the genus Vernonia of tropical and warm regions of especially North America that take their name from their loose heads of purple to rose flowers that quickly take on a rusty hue

vernoniaceous.explanation: botany , of the tribe Vernoniaceæ; characterized like Vernonia .

vernonin.explanation: A cororless, pulverulent compound, C 10 H 24 O 7 , contained in the root of Vernonia Nigritiana. It is used on the west coast of Africa as a febrifuge and is a cardiac poison, 80 parts of it producing the same effect as one part of digitalin.
A glucoside extracted from the root of a South African plant of the genus Vernonia, as a deliquescent powder, and used as a mild heart tonic.
A glucoside extracted from the root of a South African plant of the genus Vernonia , used as a mild heart tonic .

veronal.explanation: A trade-name for diethylmalonylurea, used medicinally as a hypnotic.
A barbiturate , diethylmalonyl urea or diethylbarbituric acid; barbitol, used formerly to induce sleep .
a barbiturate used as a hypnotic

veronica.explanation: A napkin or piece of cloth impressed with the face of Christ: from the legend that a woman named Veronica wiped the face of Christ with her handkerchief when he was on his way to Calvary, and that the likeness of the face was miraculously impressed upon the cloth. Also vernicle .
[ capitalized ] [NL. (Rivinus, 1690; earlier, about 1554, by Mattioli).] A genus of gamopetalous plants, of the order Scrophularineæ and tribe Digitaleæ , type of the subtribe Veroniceæ.

A portrait or representation of the face of our Savior on the alleged handkerchief of Saint Veronica, preserved at Rome; hence, a representation of this portrait, or any similar representation of the face of the Savior. Formerly called also Vernacle , and Vernicle .
A genus of scrophulariaceous plants; the speedwell. See Speedwell .
The image of Jesus's face believed to have been made on the cloth with which St Veronica wiped his face as he went to be crucified; or the cloth used for this.
A circular swinging movement of the cape , used to avoid the bull.
A flower of the genus Veronica , usually having blue petals.
any plant of the genus Veronica

verpa.explanation: a morel whose fertile portion resembles a bell and is attached to the stipe only at the top

verray.explanation: Middle English forms of very, verily.

verriculate.explanation: Having thickset tufts of parallel hairs, bristles, or branches.
Having thickset tufts of parallel hairs , bristles , or branches .

verricule.explanation: In entomology , a thickset tuft of upright parallel hairs.

verruca.explanation: A wartlike projection, as on the skin of certain amphibians or on the surface of certain pollen grains.
In botany , a wart or sessile gland produced upon various parts of plants, especially upon a thallus.
In zoology , a small, flattish, wart-like prominence; a verruciform tubercle.
[ capitalized ] A genus of cirripeds, typical of the family Verrucidæ.
A wart , especially one that grows on the foot, caused by a virus .
(pathology) a firm abnormal elevated blemish on the skin; caused by a virus

verrucano.explanation: The name given by Alpine geologists to a conglomerate of more or less imperfectly rounded fragments of white or pale-red quartz, varying in size from that of a grain of sand up to that of an egg, held together by a cement of reddish, greenish, or violet-colored silicious or talcose material.

verrucaria.explanation: A genus of angiocarpous lichens, typical of the tribe Verrucariacei.

verrucariaceous.explanation: botany , of or pertaining to the genus Verrucaria or the tribe Verrucariacei.

verruciform.explanation: Shaped like a wart or warts.
Having a shape like a wart or warts

verrucose.explanation: Covered with warts or wartlike projections.
Covered with wartlike elevations; tuberculate; warty; verrucous.
(of skin) covered with warts or projections that resemble warts

verrugas.explanation: A specific disease, often fatal, occurring in Peru; frambœsia. A prominent characteristic is the appearance of warty growths on the skin. See also yaws .
An endemic disease occurring in the Andes in Peru, characterized by warty tumors which ulcerate and bleed. It is probably due to a special bacillus, and is often fatal.

vers.explanation: A verse or verses. See verse , n.
Abbreviation of versine or versed sine .

versability.explanation: The state or quality of being versable; aptness to be turned round.
The quality or state of being versable.
The quality or state of being versable .

versableness.explanation: The character or state of being versable; versability.

versal.explanation: Ornamental letter that begins a section

versant.explanation: The slope of a side of a mountain or mountain range.
The general slope of a region.

One of the grand divisions of the animal kingdom, comprising all animals that have a backbone composed of bony or cartilaginous vertebræ, together with Amphioxus in which the backbone is represented by a simple undivided notochord. The Vertebrata always have a dorsal, or neural, cavity above the notochord or backbone, and a ventral, or visceral, cavity below it. The subdivisions or classes of Vertebrata are Mammalia, Aves, Reptilia, Amphibia, Pisces, Marsipobranchia, and Leptocardia.
