A South African monkey ( Cercopithecus pygerythrus syn. Cercopithecus Lelandii ). The upper parts are grayish green, finely specked with black. The cheeks and belly are reddish white.
A small African monkey , Cercopithecus aethiops or Chlorocebus pygerythrus, having a long tail, a black face with white cheek tufts and a greenish-brown coat
South African monkey with black face and hands

very.explanation: Used to emphasize the importance of what is specified.
Being nothing more than what is specified; mere.
very life; that is the very thing that was lost: in the latter use, often with same : as, the very same fault.
Very is occasionally used in the comparative degree, and more frequently in the superlative.
In a high degree; to no small extent; exceedingly; excessively; extremely.
to a great extent or degree ; extremely ; exceedingly
used as intensifiers; `real' is sometimes used informally for `really'; `rattling' is informal
being the exact same one; not any other:

vesalian.explanation: Vesalian foramen (foramen Vesalii) of the sphenoid bone (a small venous opening).

vese.explanation: A blast of wind; a storm; commotion.
Onset; rush; violent draught or wind.

vesica.explanation: A bladder, especially the urinary bladder or the gallbladder.
In anatomy , a bladder; a cyst; a sac; especially, the urinary bladder, or urocyst, the permanently pervious part of the allantoic sac.

A glory, or aureole, of oval shape, or composed of two arcs of circles usually represented as surrounding a divine personage. More rarely, an oval composed of two arcs not representing a glory; a solid oval, etc.
A bladder , especially the urinary bladder or the gall bladder .
The vesica piscis or oval aureole in mediaeval painting
a distensible membranous sac (usually containing liquid or gas)

vesical.explanation: vesical arteries, veins, or nerves; vesical distention.
Of or pertaining to the bladder.
of or relating to a bladder (especially the urinary bladder)

vesicant.explanation: A blistering agent, especially mustard gas, used in chemical warfare.
A vesicating agent; an epispastic or vesicatory, as cantharides; a blister.
Any material that causes blisters upon contact with the skin.
a chemical agent that causes blistering (especially mustard gas)

vesicate.explanation: To raise little bladders or blisters upon; to inflame and separate the cuticle of; to blister.

vesication.explanation: The formation of blisters; a blister.
The process of vesicating, or of raising blisters.
the formation of vesicles in or beneath the skin

vesicatory.explanation: pl. vesicatories (-riz). An irritating substance applied to the skin for the purpose of causing a blister.
Tending, or having power, to raise a blister.
a chemical agent that causes blistering (especially mustard gas)

vesicle.explanation: A small enclosed structure or cavity, especially.
A membrane-bound structure within a cell in which materials such as enzymes are transported or stored.
A sac or cyst, especially one containing fluid.
A blister of the skin.
A cavity formed in volcanic rock by entrapment of a gas bubble during solidification.
Any small bladder-like structure, cavity, cell, or the like, in a body; a membranous or vesicular vessel or cavity; a little sac or cyst. Also vesicule .
A minute hollow sphere or bubble of water or other liquid.
In petrography , a cavity in lava formed by the expansion of escaping gasbubbles, chiefly of steam.
A bladderlike vessel; a membranous cavity; a cyst; a cell.
A small bladderlike body in the substance of a vegetable, or upon the surface of a leaf.
A small, and more or less circular, elevation of the cuticle, containing a clear watery fluid.
A cavity or sac, especially one filled with fluid.
A small convex hollow prominence on the surface of a shell or a coral.

A small cavity, nearly spherical in form, and usually of the size of a pea or smaller, such as are common in some volcanic rocks. They are produced by the liberation of watery vapor in the molten mass.
A membrane -bound compartment found in a cell .
A small bladder-like cell or cavity.
A small sac or cyst or vacuole , especially one containing fluid. A blister formed in or beneath the skin, containing serum . A bleb .
A pocket of embryonic tissue that is the beginning of an organ.
A small cavity formed in volcanic rock by entrapment of a gas bubble during solidification.
a small anatomically normal sac or bladderlike structure (especially one containing fluid)

vesicoprostatic.explanation: Of or pertaining to the bladder and the prostate gland.
Of or pertaining to the bladder and prostate .

vesicorectal.explanation: Relating to the bladder and rectum .

vesicotomy.explanation: The operation of incising a bladder, usually the urinary bladder.

vesicovaginal.explanation: Of or pertaining to the bladder and the vagina.
Of or pertaining to the bladder and the vagina .

vesicular.explanation: Having the form of a vesicle.
anatomy and zoology : Of or pertaining to a vesicle; of the form or nature of a vesicle; cystic; bladdery.
vesicular tissue of the lungs; a vesicular polyp.
botany , pertaining to or consisting of vesicles; appearing as if composed of small bladders; bladdery.
geology , the epithet applied to rocks having a cellular structure, the cavities being rather large and well rounded, but not very abundant.
Of or pertaining to vesicles; esp., of or pertaining to the air vesicles, or air cells, of the lungs.
Containing, or composed of, vesicles or vesiclelike structures; covered with vesicles or bladders; vesiculate.
Having the form or structure of a vesicle.
a series of nerve cells forming one of the tracts distinguished in the spinal cord; -- also called the ganglionic column .
emphysema of the lungs, in which the air vesicles are distended and their walls ruptured.
the sound, audible on auscultation of the chest, made by the air entering and leaving the air vesicles of the lungs in respiration.
of or relating to or involving vesicles

vesicularia.explanation: The typical genus of Vesiculariidæ. V. uva is an example.
Any one of numerous species of marine Bryozoa belonging to Vesicularia and allied genera. They have delicate tubular cells attached in clusters to slender flexible stems.

vesicularity.explanation: The state or condition of being vesicular ; presence of vesicles .

vesiculate.explanation: Full of or bearing vesicles; vesicular.
Bladdery; full of, or covered with, bladders; vesicular.
To form vesicles in, as lava.
become vesicular or full of air cells
cause to become vesicular or full of air cells

vesiculation.explanation: The formation of vesicles; vesication; a number of vesicles or blebs, as of the skin in some diseases; also, a vesicular or bladdery condition; inflation.
The state of containing vesicles, or the process by which vesicles are formed.
the formation of vesicles in or beneath the skin

vesiculectomy.explanation: Excision of a portion of the seminal vesicle on either side, with the object of producing sterility.

vesiculitis.explanation: Inflammation of a vesicle, specifically of the seminal vesicles.
Inflammation of a vesicle , often specifically the seminal vesicles
inflammation of a seminal vesicle (usually in conjunction with prostatitis)

vesiculose.explanation: Bladdery; vesicular; vesiculate; composed of vesicles; covered with vesicles.
bladdery ; vesicular ; vesiculate ; composed of, or covered with, vesicles

vespa.explanation: A Linnean genus of aculeate hymenopterous insects, formerly of great extent, now restricted to certain social wasps and hornets of the modern family Vespidæ , as the common wasp, V. vulgaris , and the common hornet, V. crabro. See cuts under hornet and wasp.
A genus of Hymenoptera including the common wasps and hornets.
type genus of the Vespidae: various hornets and yellow jackets

vesper.explanation: A bell that summons worshipers to vespers.
The evening star, a name given to the planet Venus when she is east of the sun and appears after sunset; hence, the evening.

plural [⟨ LL. vespera , ML. vesperæ , ⟨ vespera , evening.] In the Roman Catholic and Greek churches, and in religious houses and as a devotional office in the Anglican Church, the sixth or next to the last of the canonical hours.
The evening star; Hesper; Venus, when seen after sunset; hence, the evening.
Of or pertaining to the evening, or to the service of vespers.
the grass finch. See under Grass .
The bell that summons worshipers to vespers ; the vesper-bell
a late afternoon or evening worship service
a planet (usually Venus) seen at sunset in the western sky

vesperal.explanation: A book containing the words and hymns to be used at vespers.
Of or relating to vesper or vespers.
That part of the antiphonarium which contains the chants for vespers.

vespers.explanation: The sixth of the seven canonical hours.
A worship service held in the late afternoon or evening in many Western Christian churches.
The time of day appointed for this service.
A service held on Sundays or holy days that includes the office of vespers.
One of the little hours of the Breviary.
The sixth of the seven canonical hours
the sixth of the seven canonical hours of the divine office; early evening; now often made a public service on Sundays

vespertilio.explanation: A Linnean genus of mammals, the fourth and last genus of the Linnean order Primates , containing 6 species, and coextensive with the modern order Chiroptera.
A genus of bats including some of the common small insectivorous species of North America and Europe.

vespertiliones.explanation: A tribe of bats including the common insectivorous bats of America and Europe, belonging to Vespertilio and allied genera. They lack a nose membrane.

vespertilionid.explanation: Any of various widely distributed insect-eating bats of the family Vespertilionidae, characterized by a long tail.
Any of very many bats of the family Vespertilionidae

vespertilionidae.explanation: the majority of common bats of temperate regions of the world

vespertilionine.explanation: Vespertilio ; of or pertaining to the subfamily Vespertilioninæ.
A bat of the subfamily Vespertilioninæ or of the vespertilionine alliance.
Of or pertaining to the Vespertiliones.
Of or pertaining to the bat family Vespertilionidae.

vespertine.explanation: Of, relating to, or occurring in the evening.
Opening or blooming in the evening.
astrology , setting after the sun: said of a planet.
botany , opening in the evening, as a flower.
capitalized ] In geology , noting one of Prof. H. D. Rogers's divisions of the Paleozoic series in Pennsylvania.
zoology , crepuscular; flying or otherwise specially active in the twilight of evening, as an insect, a bat, or a bird: as, the vespertine or evening grosbeak, Hesperiphona vespertina.
astronomy , descending from the meridian to the horizon at the time of sunset.
Of or pertaining to the evening; happening or being in the evening.
Occurring in or related to the evening .
Pertaining to animals which are principally active at dusk .
Pertaining to plants which open or bloom in the evening.

vespiary.explanation: A nest or colony of wasps.
A hornets' nest; the habitation of social wasps; also, the colony or aggregate of wasps in such a nest. See Vespa , and cut under wasp , and compare apiary and formicary.
A nest, or habitation, of insects of the wasp kind.
A nest built by a social wasp species.
A colony of wasps living in such a nest.

vespid.explanation: Any of various widely distributed insects of the family Vespidae, which includes the paper wasps, hornets, and yellow jackets.
A member of the hymenopterous family Vespidæ.
Characteristic of the wasp family Vespidae ; wasplike
Any social insect of the family Vespidae including wasps and hornets

vespidae.explanation: an arthropod family of the order Hymenoptera including: yellow jackets; hornets; mason wasps

vespine.explanation: Of, relating to, or resembling a wasp.
Of or relating to a vespid wasp of the subfamily Vespinae.
Of, pertaining to, or characteristic of wasps .

vespoid.explanation: A member of the hymenopterous superfamily Vespoidea.

vessel.explanation: A hollow utensil, such as a cup, vase, or pitcher, used as a container, especially for liquids.
A craft, especially one larger than a rowboat, designed to navigate on water.
An airship.
A duct, canal, or other tube that contains or conveys a body fluid.
One of the tubular water-conducting structures of xylem, consisting of a series of vessel elements attached end to end and connected by perforations. Vessels are found in nearly all flowering plants.
A person seen as the agent or embodiment, as of a quality.
A utensil for holding liquors and other things, as a cask, a barrel, a bottle, a kettle, a pot, a cup, or a dish.
Specifically, In metallurgy , the converter in which Bessemer steel is made. See steel .
A ship; a craft of any kind: usually a larger craft than a boat, but in law often construed to mean any floating structure.

In anatomy and zoology , any duct or canal in which a fluid, as blood or lymph, is secreted, contained, or conveyed, as an artery, vein, capillary, lymphatic, or spermatic; especially, a blood-vessel. A part or organ pervaded or well provided with vessels is said to be vascular.
In botany , same as duct —that is, a row of cells which have lost their intervening partitions, and consequently form a long continuous canal.

Figuratively, something conceived as formed to receive or contain; hence, especially in Scriptural phraseology, a person into whom anything is conceived as poured or infused, or to whom something has been imparted; a recipient.
Vessels collectively; plate.
See the adjectives.
To put into a vessel.
A hollow or concave utensil for holding anything; a hollow receptacle of any kind, as a hogshead, a barrel, a firkin, a bottle, a kettle, a cup, a bowl, etc.
A general name for any hollow structure made to float upon the water for purposes of navigation; especially, one that is larger than a common rowboat
Fig.: A person regarded as receiving or containing something; esp. (Script.), one into whom something is conceived as poured, or in whom something is stored for use.
Any tube or canal in which the blood or other fluids are contained, secreted, or circulated, as the arteries, veins, lymphatics, etc.

A continuous tube formed from superposed large cylindrical or prismatic cells (tracheæ), which have lost their intervening partitions, and are usually marked with dots, pits, rings, or spirals by internal deposition of secondary membranes; a duct.
See under Acoustic .
a woman; -- now applied humorously.
A general term for all kinds of craft designed for transportation on water, such as ships or boats .
A container of liquid, such as a glass, goblet , cup , bottle , bowl , or pitcher
A person as a container of qualities or feelings.
A tube or canal that carries fluid in an animal or plant.
To put into a vessel.
a craft designed for water transportation
an object used as a container (especially for liquids)
a tube in which a body fluid circulates

vesselful.explanation: As much as a vessel will hold.
As much as a vessel will hold; enough to fill a vessel.
As much as a vessel can hold.

vesselled.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of vessel .

vesses.explanation: A kind of worsted; also, a worsted cloth.
A kind of worsted , or the cloth made from it.

vessicnon.explanation: A soft swelling on a horse's leg; a windgall.

vessignon.explanation: A kind of soft swelling on a horse's leg; a wind-gall.

vest.explanation: A sleeveless garment, often having buttons down the front, worn usually over a shirt or blouse and sometimes as part of a three-piece suit.
A waist-length, sleeveless garment worn for protection.
A fabric trim worn to fill in the neckline of a woman's garment; a vestee.
An undershirt.
An ecclesiastical vestment.

To place (authority, property, or rights, for example) in the control of a person or group, especially to give someone an immediate right to present or future possession or enjoyment of (an estate, for example). Used with in .
To invest or endow (a person or group) with something, such as power or rights. Used with with .
To clothe or robe, as in ecclesiastical vestments.
To become legally vested.
To dress oneself, especially in ecclesiastical vestments.
with.
in.
vest money in land. [Rare.] Imp. Dict.
in.
An article of clothing covering the person; an outer garment; a vestment.
Figuratively, garment; dress; array; vesture.
A body-garment for men's wear, at different times of distinct types
A body-garment of later times; especially, the waistcoat in the ordinary modern sense—that is, a short garment without sleeves, buttoning down the front, and having the back concealed by the coat.
An outer garment, or part of such a garment, for women.
An undergarment knitted or woven on the stocking-loom. Vest and undervest are more common in England; undershirt in the United States.
To come or descend; to be fixed; to take effect, as a title or right; -- followed by in .
An article of clothing covering the person; an outer garment; a vestment; a dress; a vesture; a robe.
Any outer covering; array; garb.
Specifically, a waistcoat, or sleeveless body garment, for men, worn under the coat.
To clothe with, or as with, a vestment, or garment; to dress; to robe; to cover, surround, or encompass closely.
To clothe with authority, power, or the like; to put in possession; to invest; to furnish; to endow; -- followed by with before the thing conferred.
To place or give into the possession or discretion of some person or authority; to commit to another; -- with in before the possessor.
To invest; to put.
To clothe with possession; ; also, to give a person an immediate fixed right of present or future enjoyment of.
A loose robe or outer garment worn historically by men in Arabic or Middle Eastern countries.
A sleeveless garment that buttons down the front, worn over a shirt , and often as part of a suit ; a waistcoat .
A sleeveless garment, often with a low-cut neck, usually worn under a shirt or blouse .
A sleeveless top , typically with identifying colours or logos, worn by an athlete or member of a sports team.
Any sleeveless outer garment , often for a purpose such as identification, safety, or storage.
: (commonly used of financial arrangements) To become vested , to become permanent .
clothe oneself in ecclesiastical garments
clothe formally; especially in ecclesiastical robes
place (authority, property, or rights) in the control of a person or group of persons
a man's sleeveless garment worn underneath a coat
a collarless men's undergarment for the upper part of the body
provide with power and authority
become legally vested

vesta.explanation: a short match , made of wood or wax

vestal.explanation: Of or relating to Vesta.
Relating to or characteristic of the vestal virgins.
Chaste; pure.
A vestal virgin.
A woman who is a virgin.
A nun.
Among the ancient Romans, a virgin consecrated to Vesta and to the service of watching the sacred fire, which was kept perpetually burning upon her altar.
Hence A virgin; a woman of spotless chastity; sometimes, a virgin who devotes her life entirely to the service of religion; a nun; a religieuse.
In entomology : The geometrid moth Sterrha sacraria : popularly so called in England, A gossamer-winged butterfly; any member of the Vestales.
Of or pertaining to Vesta, the virgin goddess of the hearth; hence, pure; chaste.
A virgin consecrated to Vesta, and to the service of watching the sacred fire, which was to be perpetually kept burning upon her altar.
A virgin; a woman pure and chaste; also, a nun.
Of or pertaining to Vesta , the virgin goddess of the hearth.
Pure ; chaste .
A virgin consecrated to Vesta, and to the service of watching the sacred fire, which was to be perpetually kept burning upon her altar.
A female virgin; a woman who has never had sexual relations.
A nun .
of or relating to Vesta
in a state of sexual virginity
a chaste woman

vestalia.explanation: In Roman antiquity , the yearly festival of Vesta, which occurred on the ninth of July.

vested.explanation: Settled, fixed, or absolute; being without contingency.
Having full ownership rights, especially after certain conditions such as a period of service, have been met.
Dressed or clothed, especially in ecclesiastical vestments.

heraldry , clothed; draped: used especially when the clothing is of a different tincture from the rest of the bearing. This blazon is more usual when only a part of the body is represented. Also clothed .
Not in a state of contingency or suspension; fixed.

a legacy the right to which commences in præsenti , and does not depend on a contingency; as, a legacy to one to be paid when he attains to twenty-one years of age is a vested legacy , and if the legatee dies before the testator, his representative shall receive it.
an estate settled, to remain to a determined person, after the particular estate is spent.
: (law) settled , fixed or absolute , with no contingencies .
: dressed or clothed , especially in vestments
Simple past tense and past participle of vest .
fixed and absolute and without contingency

vestee.explanation: A garment worn by women as a blouse front under a sweater or jacket.
a dickey , notably made to resemble a vest and be worn under a coat

vester.explanation: One who invests money or other property; an investor.

vestiarian.explanation: Of or pertaining to a vestiary or vestments.
Of or pertaining to a vestiary or vestments .

vestiary.explanation: A dressing room, cloakroom, or vestry.
A room or place for the keeping of vestments, garments, or clothes; a wardrobe.
A vestibule; a place of entrance; a court.
A wardrobe; a robing room; a vestry.
A dressing room or storeroom for clothes, especially in a church or other religious house.

vestibular.explanation: Of, relating to, or serving as a vestibule.
Of or pertaining to a vestibule; like a vestibule.
Of or pertaining to a vestibule in a building.
Of or pertaining to a vestibule (body cavity).
relating to the sense of equilibrium

vestibulate.explanation: anatomy and zoology , having a vestibule, in any sense; formed into a vestibule; vestibular.

vestibule.explanation: A small entrance hall or passage between the outer door and the interior of a house or building.
An enclosed area at the end of a passenger car on a railroad train.
A body cavity, chamber, or channel that leads to or is an entrance to another body cavity.

In Bryozoa of the suborder Cryptostomata , a tubular shaft which lies above and leads to the mouth of the zoœcium. This vestibule or vestibular shaft may be crossed by diaphragms or hemisepta and is surrounded by vesicular tissue or a solid calcareous deposit.

In car-building , a car-platform inclosed above and on two sides and connected by a bellows-like extension with the similarly inclosed platform of the next car. Each extension carries an iron doorframe called a face-plate. When two cars are coupled together the opposing face-plates are pressed together by springs, which at the same time allow them to slip over one another with the motion of the cars. The permanent structure of the vestibule includes doors on each side, at the steps, and hinged platforms to cover the steps when the doors are closed.

A passage, hall, or antechamber next the outer door of a house, from which doors open into the various inner rooms; a porch; a lobby; a hall; a narthex. See cuts under opisthodomus, porch , and pronaos.

In anatomy : A part of the labyrinth of the ear, the common or central cavity, between the semicircular canals and the cochlea, communicating permanently with the former, and temporarily or permanently with the latter, from the proper membranous cavity of which it is generally shut off subsequently, opening into the tympanum or middle ear by the fenestra ovalis, which, however, is closed in life by a membrane. See cuts under car and temporal.

A triangular space between the nymphæ or labia minora of the human female and some anthropoid apes, containing the orifice of the urethra, or meatus urinarius. More fully called vestibule of the vulva and vestibulum vaginæ.
A part of the left ventricular cavity of the heart, adjoining the root of the aorta.

In zoology : A depression of the body-wall of sundry infusorians, as Paramecium and Noctiluca , leading to the oral and sometimes also to the anal aperture, and thus connected, by means of an esophageal canal, with the endosarc. See Vorticella, Noctiluca , and cut under Paramecium .
In polyzoans, an outer chamber of a cell of the polyzoary, which opens on the surface, and into which, in some forms, the pharynx and anus both open.
The porch or entrance into a house; a hall or antechamber next the entrance; a lobby; a porch; a hall.
See under Ear .
a triangular space between the nymphæ, in which the orifice of the urethra is situated.
a train of passenger cars having the space between the end doors of adjacent cars inclosed, so as to admit of leaving the doors open to provide for intercommunication between all the cars.
To furnish with a vestibule or vestibules.
A passage , hall or room , such as a lobby , between the outer door and the interior of a building .
An enclosed entrance at the end of a railway passenger car.
Any of a number of body cavities , serving as or resembling an entrance to another bodily space.
any of various bodily cavities leading to another cavity (as of the ear or vagina)
a large entrance or reception room or area

vestibulum.explanation: In anatomy and zoology , a vestibule.
A cavity into which, in certain bryozoans, the esophagus and anus open.
A cavity into which, in certain bryozoans , the esophagus and anus open.

vestige.explanation: A visible trace, evidence, or sign of something that once existed but exists or appears no more.

A rudimentary or degenerate, usually nonfunctioning, structure that is the remnant of an organ or part that was fully developed or functioning in a preceding generation or an earlier stage of development.

A footprint; a footstep; a track; a trace; hence, a mark, impression, or appearance of something which is no longer present or in existence; a sensible evidence or visible sign of something absent, lost, or perished; remains of something passed away.
In biology , any vestigial organ or tissue, having little or no utility, but corresponding to a useful part existing in some lower animal. See vestigial and rudiment , 3.
The mark of the foot left on the earth; a track or footstep; a trace; a sign; hence, a faint mark or visible sign left by something which is lost, or has perished, or is no longer present; remains.
A small, degenerate, or imperfectly developed part or organ which has been more fully developed in some past generation.
The mark of the foot left on the earth; a track or footstep; a trace; a sign;
A faint mark or visible sign left by something which is lost, or has perished, or is no longer present; remains .
a vestigial organ ; a non-functional organ or body part that was once functional in an evolutionary ancestor
an indication that something has been present

vestigial.explanation: Of, relating to, or constituting a vestige.
Occurring or persisting as a rudimentary or degenerate structure.
Of or pertaining to a vestige or remnant; like a vestige.
Of or pertaining to a vestige or remnant ; like a trace from the past.
Not fully developed in mature animals.
not fully developed in mature animals

vestigium.explanation: In anatomy , a vestige; a vestigial structure of any kind; a trace, as the pit which marks the closed foramen ovale between the right and left auricles of the heart.

vesting.explanation: Cloth especially made for men's waistcoats: most commonly in the plural.
Cloth for vests; a vest pattern.
The entitlement of an employee to receive the full benefit of a pension at normal retirement age or a reduced pension upon early retirement even upon change of employer before retirement.
The entitlement of an employee to exercise a stock option after a predetermined period of time.

vestiture.explanation: The manufacture or preparation of cloth.
In zoology , the hairs, scales, etc., covering a surface: as, the vestiture of the thorax of an insect.
The hairs of plants , invertebrates and other non-mammalian organisms, taken as a whole.
Investiture (of a person with a specific role, powers etc.).

vestlet.explanation: A tubicolous sea-anemone of the genus Cerianthus , as C. borealis.

Any one of several species of actinians belonging to the genus Cerianthus. These animals have a long, smooth body tapering to the base, and two separate circles of tentacles around the mouth. They form a tough, flexible, feltlike tube with a smooth internal lining, in which they dwell, whence the name.
Any of several species of actinian of the genus Cerianthus, with a long, smooth, tapering body and two separate circles of tentacles around the mouth.

vestment.explanation: A garment, especially a robe or gown worn as an indication of office or state.
Any of the ritual robes worn by members of the clergy, acolytes, or other assistants at services or rites, especially a garment worn at the celebration of the Eucharist.
A covering or garment; some part of clothing or dress; an article of clothing; especially, some part of outer clothing; specifically, a ceremonial or official robe or garment.

Eccles. : One of the garments worn, in addition to the cassock and ordinary dress, by the clergy and their assistants, choristers, etc., during divine service and the administration of the sacraments; especially, one of the garments so worn by the celebrant, deacon, and subdeacon during the celebration of the eucharist; specifically, the chasuble, or the chasuble with the other eucharistic garments and ornaments, especially the amice, stole, and maniple. One of the cloths or coverings of the altar.
A covering or garment; some part of clothing or dress.
A robe or gown worn as an indication of office .
Any of the robes worn by members of the clergy etc., especially a garment worn at the celebration of the Eucharist .
gown (especially ceremonial garments) worn by the clergy

vestmental.explanation: of or relating to or resembling a vestment

vestmented.explanation: dressed in ceremonial garments especially clerical vestment

vestry.explanation: A room in or attached to a church where the clergy put on their vestments and where these robes and other sacred objects are stored; a sacristy.
A room in a church used for meetings and classes.
A committee of members elected to administer the temporal affairs of a parish.
A business meeting of parishioners in a parish.
A room, or sometimes a separate building, attached to a church, where the vestments of the clergy, and sometimes the sacred vessels and other treasures of the church, are kept.
In non-liturgical churches , a room or building attached to a church, and used for the Sabbath-school, the weekly prayer-meetings, religious services, etc.; a chapel.
In English ecclesiastical law , and in American colonial law : A meeting of the inhabitants or ratepayers of a parish for the despatch of the official business of the parish.
A meeting or a board consisting of representatives of the ratepayers at large, all of whom are entitled to vote in their election.
In the Prot. Epis. Ch. in the United States of America, a committee (chosen annually by the members of the congregation) who, in conjunction with the churchwardens, manage its temporal affairs.

Any right or power of authoritatively forbidding or effectively negativing, or the exercise of such right or power; prohibition; interdict.

Such a power may be absolute, as in the case of the Tribunes of the People in ancient Rome, or limited, as in the case of the President of the United States. Called also the veto power .

To be in a state of great activity, excitement, or agitation.

A distinctive emotional quality or atmosphere that is sensed or experienced by someone. Often used in the plural.

In physics , an oscillating, reciprocating, or any kind of stationary motion made by a body, as a pendulum, musical cord, elastic plate, or mass of air, when forced from the position, figure, or volume of equilibrium, under the influence of forces of restitution.
In medicine , same as fremitus .

In natural history , movement to and fro, especially when quick, continuous, regular, and of little amplitude; a quivering or shivering motion; tremulousness; tremor: as, the vibration of aspen-leaves on their compressed petioles in the breeze; the vibration of the ear-drum under sound-waves; the vibration of a fly's wings in flight.
The act of vibrating, or the state of being vibrated, or in vibratory motion; quick motion to and fro; oscillation, as of a pendulum or musical string.

A limited reciprocating motion of a particle of an elastic body or medium in alternately opposite directions from its position of equilibrium, when that equilibrium has been disturbed, as when a stretched cord or other body produces musical notes, or particles of air transmit sounds to the ear. The path of the particle may be in a straight line, in a circular arc, or in any curve whatever.
the maximum displacement of a vibrating particle or body from its position of rest.

any part of the path described by a particle or body in making a complete vibration, in distinction from other parts, as while moving from one extreme to the other, or on one side of the line of rest, in distinction from the opposite. Two particles are said to be in the same phase when they are moving in the same direction and with the same velocity, or in corresponding parts of their paths.
The act of vibrating or the condition of being vibrated
Any periodic process , especially a rapid linear motion of a body about an equilibrium position
A single complete vibrating motion

A small assemblage of houses, less than a town or city, and larger than a hamlet.
In law , sometimes a manor; sometimes a whole parish or subdivision of it; most commonly an outpart of a parish, consisting of a few houses separate from the rest.
A small assemblage of houses in the country, less than a town or city.
a kind of two-wheeled pleasure carriage without a top.
A rural habitation of size between a hamlet and a town .
A rural habitation that has a church , but no market .
A planned community such as a retirement community or shopping district .
a community of people smaller than a town
a settlement smaller than a town
a mainly residential district of Manhattan; `the Village' became a home for many writers and artists in the 20th century

villagehood.explanation: The state of being a village .
The people and culture of a village.

villagelike.explanation: Resembling a village or some aspect of a village.

villager.explanation: a person who lives in, or comes from, a village
a worker unit (Synonyms: peasant , peon , serf )
one who has lived in a village most of their life

villain.explanation: A wicked or evil person; a scoundrel.
A dramatic or fictional character who is typically at odds with the hero.
Something said to be the cause of particular trouble or an evil.
A peasant regarded as vile and brutish.
A member of the lowest class of unfree persons during the prevalence of the feudal system; a feudal serf.
Hence An ignoble or base-born person generally; a boor, peasant, or clown.
A man of ignoble or base character; especially, one who is guilty or capable of gross wickedness; a scoundrel; a knave; a rascal; a rogue: often used humorously in affectionate or jocose reproach.
One who holds lands by a base, or servile, tenure, or in villenage; a feudal tenant of the lowest class, a bondman or servant.
A baseborn or clownish person; a boor.
A vile, wicked person; a man extremely depraved, and capable or guilty of great crimes; a deliberate scoundrel; a knave; a rascal; a scamp.
this sense?) (The addition of quotations indicative of this usage is being sought): A vile , wicked person.
The bad person in a work of fiction; often the main antagonist of the hero .
the principal bad character in a film or work of fiction
a wicked or evil person; someone who does evil deliberately

villainage.explanation: The condition of a villain or peasant.
the legal status or condition of servitude of a villein or feudal serf

villainess.explanation: A woman who is a villain.

villainous.explanation: Being or behaving like a villain.
Appropriate to or characteristic of a villain.
Proceeding from, or showing, extreme depravity; suited to a villain.
Sorry; mean; mischievous; -- in a familiar sense.
a judgment that casts reproach on the guilty person.
of, relating to, or appropriate to a villain
obnoxious , offensive or reprehensible in nature or behaviour ; nefarious

villainously.explanation: In a villainous manner; in the manner of a villain ; evilly .

villainousness.explanation: The state or character of being villainous; baseness; extreme depravity; vileness.
The state or condition of being villainous ; wicked behaviour.
the quality of evil by virtue of villainous behavior

villainy.explanation: The condition of a villain or serf; rusticity.
The character of being villainous; the qualities characteristic of a villain; extreme depravity; atrocious wickedness.
Discourteous or abusive language; opprobrious terms.
Disgraceful conduct; conduct unbecoming a gentleman.
Synonyms Baseness, turpitude, atrocity, infamy. See nefarious .
The quality or state of being a villain, or villainous; extreme depravity; atrocious wickedness.
Abusive, reproachful language; discourteous speech; foul talk.
The act of a villain; a deed of deep depravity; a crime.
Evil or vicious character or behaviour .
the quality of evil by virtue of villainous behavior

villanage.explanation: The state of a villain, or serf; base servitude; tenure on condition of doing the meanest services for the lord.

villancico.explanation: A kind of song, akin to the madrigal, popular in Spain in the fifteenth century, consisting of seven-lined stanzas.

villanella.explanation: An Italian rustic partsong without accompaniment, the precursor of the more refined and artistic canzonetta and madrigal. It was not supposed to be amenable to the strict rules of composition. Also villotte .
An old rustic dance, accompanied with singing.
An old rustic dance , accompanied by singing .

villanelle.explanation: A 19-line poem of fixed form consisting of five tercets and a final quatrain on two rhymes, with the first and third lines of the first tercet repeated alternately as a refrain closing the succeeding stanzas and joined as the final couplet of the quatrain.
A poem in a fixed form borrowed from the French, and allied to the virelay.
A poem written in tercets with but two rhymes, the first and third verse of the first stanza alternating as the third verse in each successive stanza and forming a couplet at the close.
a type of poetry , consisting of five tercets and one quatrain , with only two rhymes .

villatic.explanation: Of or pertaining to a farm or a village; rural.
Of or pertaining to a farm or village ; rural .

villein.explanation: One of a class of feudal serfs who held the legal status of freemen in their dealings with all people except their lord.
(Middle Ages) a person who is bound to the land and owned by the feudal lord

villeinage.explanation: The legal status or condition of a villein.
The legal tenure by which a villein held land.
A tenure of lands and tenements by base—that is, menial—services.
The state of being a villein .
A feudal system involving villeins ; serfdom .
tenure by which a villein held land
the legal status or condition of servitude of a villein or feudal serf

villiaumite.explanation: Sodium fluoride, occurring in small grains of a carmine color and isometric crystallization in the nepheline-syenite of the Los Islands.
A rare toxic halide mineral composed of sodium fluoride .

villiform.explanation: Thin, elongated, and densely arranged, like villi.
Having the form or appearance of villi; like close-set fibers, either hard or soft.

villitis.explanation: Inflammation of the coronary cushion or secreting substance of the hoof-wall of the horse, leading to the formation of imperfect horn. Also called coronitis .

villoid.explanation: botany , pertaining to or resembling villi or fine hairs; villiform.

villosity.explanation: A villous formation, surface, or coating.
A number of villi together; a roughness or shagginess resulting from villiform processes; a nap or pile, as of an organic membrane; fine or short hispidity; pilosity.
In botany , the state of being villous, or covered with long, soft hairs: such hairs collectively.
A coating of long, slender hairs.

villous.explanation: Of, relating to, resembling, or covered with villi.
botany , pubescent with long and soft hairs which are not interwoven
Abounding in, or covered with, fine hairs, or a woolly substance; shaggy with soft hairs; nappy.
hairy , covered with soft long hair

villus.explanation: A minute projection arising from a mucous membrane, especially.
One of the numerous vascular projections of the small intestine.
One of the fingerlike projections of the chorion that contribute to the formation of the placenta in mammals.

In anatomy : One of numerous minute vascular projections from the mucous membrane of the intestine, of a conical, cylindric, clubbed, or filiform shape, consisting essentially of a lacteal vessel as a central axis, with an arteriole and a veinlet, inclosed in a layer of epithelium, with the basement membrane and muscular tissue of the mucous membrane, and cellular or reticular tissue.

One of the little vascular tufts or processes of the shaggy chorion of an ovum or embryo, in later stages of development entering into the formation of the fetal part of the placenta. See cut under uterus , Some villiform part or process of various animals. See cut under hydranth .
In botany , one of the long, straight, and soft, hairs which sometimes cover the fruit, flowers, and other parts of plants.
One of the minute papillary processes on certain vascular membranes; a villosity.
Fine hairs on plants, resembling the pile of velvet.
a small projection from a mucous membrane , particularly those found in the intestines
a minute hairlike projection on mucous membrane

vim.explanation: Liveliness or energy; enthusiasm. synonym : vigor .
Power; force; energy; spirit; activity; vigor.
a healthy capacity for vigorous activity
an imaginative lively style (especially style of writing)

vimana.explanation: In the architecture of India, a tower-like structure marking the principal or central part of a temple. It is usually pyramidal or spire-like in shape, several stories high, and elaborately sculptured, and is assumed to contain the central and most sacred shrine.

vimen.explanation: In botany , a long and flexible shoot of a plant.
A long, slender, flexible shoot or branch.

viminal.explanation: Of or pertaining to twigs ; consisting of twigs; producing twigs.

vimineous.explanation: botany , made up of or bearing long, flexible twigs; viminal.
Of or pertaining to twigs; made of pliant twigs.
Producing long, slender twigs or shoots.
Producing long, slender twigs or shoots .

vimpa.explanation: A veil or shawl worn over the shoulders of servers who carry the mitre and crosier during liturgical functions when they are not being used by the bishop , in the Roman Catholic , Anglican , and some other western churches.

vina.explanation: A stringed instrument of India that has a long, fretted fingerboard with resonating gourds at each end.

vinaceous.explanation: Having the color of red wine.
Belonging to, or like, wine or grapes.
Of the color of wine, especially of red wine.
of the colour of red wine

vinage.explanation: The addition of spirit to wine to preserve it or enable it to withstand transportation.

vinaigrette.explanation: A cold sauce or dressing made of vinegar or lemon juice and oil, often flavored with finely chopped onions, herbs, and other seasonings.
A small decorative bottle or container with a perforated top, used for holding an aromatic preparation such as smelling salts.
A small bottle or box used for carrying about the person some drug having a strong and pungent odor, commonly aromatic vinegar.
A small two-wheeled vehicle to be drawn like a Bath Chair by a boy or a man.
A sauce, made of vinegar, oil, and other ingredients, -- used esp. for cold meats.
A small perforated box for holding aromatic vinegar contained in a sponge, or a smelling bottle for smelling salts; -- called also vinegarette .
A small, two-wheeled vehicle, like a Bath chair, to be drawn or pushed by a boy or man.
A sauce, made of vinegar, oil, and other ingredients, used especially for cold meats, or as a salad dressing.
A small perforated box for holding aromatic vinegar contained in a sponge, or a smelling bottle for smelling salts; called also vinegarette .
A small, two-wheeled vehicle, like a Bath chair, to be drawn or pushed by a boy or man.
a sort of Russian salad, originally using the French salad dressing.
oil and vinegar with mustard and garlic

vinaigrier.explanation: The whipscorpion, Thelyphonus giganteus : same as grampus , 6. See vinegerone .

vinalia.explanation: Roman antiquity , a double festival, celebrated on April 22d and on August 19th, at which an offering of wine from the vintage of the preceding autumn was made to Jupiter.

vinasse.explanation: The residue left in a still after the process of distillation.

The waste liquor remaining in the process of making beet sugar, -- used in the manufacture of potassium carbonate.
The waste liquor remaining in the process of making beet sugar , used in the manufacture of potassium carbonate .

vinblastine.explanation: An alkaloid, C 46 H 58 N 4 O 9 , obtained from the Madagascar periwinkle and used as an antineoplastic drug.
A particular drug used in chemotherapy .
periwinkle plant derivative used as an antineoplastic drug (trade name Velban) that disrupts cell division

vinca.explanation: Any of various periwinkles of the genus Vinca or the closely related genus Catharanthus.
A genus of gamopetalous plants, of the order Apocynaceæ , tribe Plumerieæ , and subtribe Euplumerieæ.
Any of several evergreen shrubs , of the genus Vinca , including the periwinkle

vincent.explanation: The victim or dupe in a betting game, especially bowls.

vincetoxicum.explanation: The officinal name of the swallowwort or tamepoison, Cynanchum ( Asclepias ) Vincetoxicum , the root of which was formerly esteemed as a counter-poison. Both root and leaves have emetic properties.
genus of chiefly tropical American vines having cordate leaves and large purple or greenish cymose flowers; supposedly having powers as an antidote

vincetoxin.explanation: The name given to two yellow, amorphous, pulverulent compounds, C 16 H 12 O 6 , contained in powdered asclepias root, Cynanchum Vincitoxicum. They melt at 59° C. One dissolves in water, the other does not.

A glucoside extracted from the root of the white swallowwort ( Vincetoxicum officinale , a plant of the Asclepias family) as a bitter yellow amorphous substance; -- called also asclepiadin , and cynanchin .
A glucoside extracted from the root of the white swallowwort .

vincibility.explanation: The state or character of being vincible; capability of being conquered.
The quality or state of being vincible, vincibleness.

vincible.explanation: Capable of being overcome or defeated.

ignorance within the individual's control and for which, therefore, he is responsible before God.
Capable of being defeated or overcome ; assailable or vulnerable

vincibleness.explanation: The quality or state of being vincible.
The quality or state of being vincible .

vincristine.explanation: An alkaloid, C 46 H 56 N 4 O 10 , obtained from the Madagascar periwinkle and used as an antineoplastic drug for a variety of neoplasms.
A particular drug used in chemotherapy .
periwinkle plant derivative used as an antineoplastic drug (trade name Oncovin); used to treat cancer of the lymphatic system

vinculum.explanation: A bar drawn over two or more algebraic terms to indicate that they are to be treated as a single term.
A bandlike structure, such as a ligament.
A bond of union; a bond; a tie.

In algebra , a character in the form of a stroke or brace drawn over a quantity when it consists of several terms, in order to connect them together as one quantity and show that they are to be multiplied or divided, etc., together: thus, , indicates that the sum of a and b is to be multiplied by c; whereas the expression without this character would indicate simply that b is to be multiplied by c , and the product added to adjective
In anatomy , a tendinous or ligamentous band uniting certain parts; a frenum.
A bond of union; a tie.
A straight, horizontal mark placed over two or more members of a compound quantity, which are to be subjected to the same operation, as in the expression x2 + y2 - x + y.
A band or bundle of fibers; a frænum.
A commissure uniting the two main tendons in the foot of certain birds.
A bond or link signifying union.
Any symbol used to group some of the terms in an expression , indicating that that part of the calculation should be done before other parts.
A horizontal line over the top of some of the terms in an expression, indicating that that part of the calculation is to be done before other parts.
Specifically, the horizontal line between the numerator and denominator in a fraction .
A ligament that limits the movement of an organ or part.

vindaloo.explanation: A highly seasoned dish of Indian origin made from meat or seafood cooked in a sauce of vinegar, red chilis, garlic, tamarind, and spices.
A blend of chilis , tamarind , ginger , cumin , and mustard seeds, originally from Goa .
A hot curry made with this spice .

vindemial.explanation: Of or pertaining to a vintage, or grape harvest.
Of or pertaining to a vintage , or grape harvest .

vindemiatrix.explanation: A star of the constellation Virgo (which see).

vindicability.explanation: The quality of being vindicable, or the capability of support or justification.

vindicate.explanation: To clear of accusation, blame, suspicion, or doubt with supporting arguments or proof.

To demonstrate or prove the value or validity of; justify.
To exact revenge for; avenge.
vindicate an official.
and Assert, Defend, Maintain , etc. See assert .
To lay claim to; to assert a right to; to claim.
To maintain or defend with success; to prove to be valid; to assert convincingly; to sustain against assault.
To support or maintain as true or correct, against denial, censure, or objections; to defend; to justify.
To maintain, as a law or a cause, by overthrowing enemies.
To liberate; to set free; to deliver.
To avenge; to punish.

To justify by providing evidence .

To provide justification for.

justified , avenged or cleared of blame
freed from any question of guilt

vindication.explanation: The act of vindicating or condition of being vindicated.
Something that provides evidence or support for a claim or argument.
The act of vindicating, or the state of being vindicated.
The act of supporting by proof or legal process; the proving of anything to be true or just: as, the vindication of a title, claim, or right.
Defense from wrong or oppression, by force or otherwise; maintenance of a cause against an assailant or enemy: as, the vindication of the rights of man; the vindication of liberties.
The act of vindicating, or the state of being vindicated; defense; justification against denial or censure.
The claiming a thing as one's own; the asserting of a right or title in, or to, a thing.
the act of vindicating or the state of being vindicated
evidence , facts , statements or arguments that justify a claim or belief
the act of vindicating or defending against criticism or censure etc.
the justification for some act or belief

given or inflicted in requital according to merits or deserts
of or relating to or having the nature of retribution

vindictive.explanation: Marked by or resulting from a desire to hurt; spiteful.
Disposed to revenge; prompted or characterized by revenge; revengeful.
Having a tendency to seek revenge when wronged .
disposed to seek revenge or intended for revenge
showing malicious ill will and a desire to hurt; motivated by spite

vindictiveness.explanation: The state or character of being vindictive; revengeful spirit; revengefulness.

vine.explanation: A weak-stemmed plant that derives its support from climbing, twining, or creeping along a surface.
The stem of such a plant.
A grapevine.
Grapevines considered as a group.
To form or develop like a vine.

A climbing plant with a woody stem, the fruit of which is known as the grape; a grape-vine: often called specifically the vine. It is of the genus Vitis , and of numerous species and varieties, the primary species being the V. vinifera of the Old World. See grape and Vitis.

Any plant with a long slender stem that trails on the ground, or climbs and supports itself by winding round a fixed object, or by seizing any fixed thing with its tendrils or claspers: as, the hop- vine ; the vines of melons.
A plant of Jamaica, Forsteronia floribunda of the Apocynaceæ , yielding an excellent caoutchouc
Aspidiotus uvæ , a small, round, inconspicuous scale occurring on grapecanes in the United States; also. A. vitis , a closely allied species occurring in Europe.

The grape-vine filbert-gall of Cecidomyia vitis-coryloides , a rounded mass of galls 1½ or 2 inches in diameter, springing from a common center, and composed of from ten to forty woolly greenish galls, the larger ones the size and shape of a filbert
The grape-vine tomato-gall of Lasioptera vitis , a mass of irregular succulent swellings on the leaf-stalks of the vine, yellowish-green with rosy cheeks, or sometimes entirely red.
The grape-vine apple-gall of Cecidomyia vitis-pomum , a globular, fleshy, greenish gall, nearly an inch in diameter, attached by a rough base to the stem of the vine
The leaf-gall of the above-ground form of Phylloxera vastatrix .
Sesia polistiformis , a small hornet-moth whose larva bores in the roots of the vine.
Vitis Labrusca , the northern fox-grape of America. See Vitis .
Any woody climbing plant which bears grapes.

Hence, a climbing or trailing plant; the long, slender stem of any plant that trails on the ground, or climbs by winding round a fixed object, or by seizing anything with its tendrils, or claspers; a creeper
a small kind of squash.

any one of several species of beetles which are injurious to the leaves or branches of the grapevine. Among the more important species are the grapevine fidia (see Fidia ), the spotted Pelidnota (see Rutilian ), the vine fleabeetle ( Graptodera chalybea ), the rose beetle (see under Rose ), the vine weevil, and several species of Colaspis and Anomala .
A clearwing moth ( Ægeria polistiformis ), whose larva bores in the roots of the grapevine and is often destructive.
an old and fruitless branch of a vine.
any one of several species of moths belonging to Alypia and allied genera, whose larvæ feed on the leaves of the grapevine.
a plant louse, esp. the phylloxera that injuries the grapevine.
any one of numerous species of insect larvæ that are injurious to the grapevine.
any one of several species of leaf hoppers which suck the sap of the grapevine, especially Erythroneura vitis . See Illust. of Grape hopper, under Grape .
the larva of any species of geometrid moths which feed on the leaves of the grapevine, especially Cidaria diversilineata .
a small moth ( Desmia maculalis ) whose larva makes a nest by rolling up the leaves of the grapevine. The moth is brownish black, spotted with white.
the phylloxera.

a fungous growth which forms a white, delicate, cottony layer upon the leaves, young shoots, and fruit of the vine, causing brown spots upon the green parts, and finally a hardening and destruction of the vitality of the surface. The plant has been called Oidium Tuckeri , but is now thought to be the conidia-producing stage of an Erysiphe .
a plant named in the Bible (Deut. xxxii. 32), now thought to be identical with the apple of Sodom. See Apple of Sodom, under Apple .
a small black sawfiy ( Selandria vitis ) whose larva feeds upon the leaves of the grapevine. The larvæ stand side by side in clusters while feeding.
the larva of the vine sawfly.
a climbing plant ( Cissus acida ) related to the grapevine, and having acid leaves. It is found in Florida and the West Indies.
any one of several species of hawk moths. The larvæ feed on grapevine leaves.
See Vine borer (a) above, and Wound gall, under Wound .
the climbing plant that produces grapes
any plant of the genus Vitis
by extension, any similar climbing or trailing plant
a plant with a weak stem that derives support from climbing, twining, or creeping along a surface

vinea.explanation: In Roman antiquity , a shed or gallery movable on wheels, serving to protect besiegers and to connect their works.

vineal.explanation: Of or pertaining to vines; containing vines.
Of or pertaining to vines ; containing vines.

vined.explanation: Having leaves like those of the vine; ornamented with vine leaves.
Having leaves like those of the vine ; ornamented with vine leaves.

vinedresser.explanation: A person who cultivates and prunes grapevines.
One who dresses, trims, prunes, and cultivates vines.
The larva of a sphingid moth, Ampelophaga ( Darapsa or Everyx ) myron.
One who cultivates, prunes, or cares for, grapevines; a laborer in a vineyard.
One who works in a vineyard .

vinegar.explanation: A sour liquid containing acetic acid, produced by fermenting a solution (such as wine or fermented rice) containing ethanol produced by a previous fermentation, used as a condiment and preservative.
Sourness of speech or mood; ill temper.
Liveliness and enthusiasm; vim.
Dilute and impure acetic acid, obtained by the acetous fermentation.
Anything really or metaphorically sour; sourness of temper. Also used attributively to signify sour or crabbed.
In pharmacy , a solution of a medicinal substance in acetic acid, or vinegar; acetum.
To convert into vinegar; to make like vinegar; to render sour or sharp.
A sour liquid used as a condiment, or as a preservative, and obtained by the spontaneous ( acetous ) fermentation, or by the artificial oxidation, of wine, cider, beer, or the like.
Hence, anything sour; -- used also metaphorically.
strong acetic acid highly flavored with aromatic substances.
See 4th Mother .
acetic acid.
See under Thief .

a minute nematode worm ( Leptodera oxophila , or Anguillula acetiglutinis ), commonly found in great numbers in vinegar, sour paste, and other fermenting vegetable substances; -- called also vinegar worm .
a fanciful name of an apparatus designed to oxidize alcohol to acetic acid by means of platinum.
See 4th Mother .
the stag-horn sumac ( Rhus typhina ), whose acid berries have been used to intensify the sourness of vinegar.
See under Wood .
A sour liquid formed by the fermentation of alcohol used as a condiment or preservative ; a dilute solution of acetic acid .
Any variety of vinegar.
To season with vinegar.
dilute acetic acid
sour-tasting liquid produced usually by oxidation of the alcohol in wine or cider and used as a condiment or food preservative

vinegariness.explanation: a sourness resembling that of vinegar

vinegarishness.explanation: The state or condition of being vinegarish .
a sourness resembling that of vinegar

vinegarweed.explanation: aromatic plant of western United States

vinegary.explanation: Having the taste, smell, or nature of vinegar.
Having the nature of vinegar; sour; unamiable.
of a liquid, having turned partially or fully to vinegar.

vinegerone.explanation: The whip-tailed scorpion, Thelyphonus giganteus : so called on account of the strong vinegar-Iike odor of an acid secretion noticeable when the creature is alarmed. Also called vinaigrier and vinegar-maker. See cut under Pedipalpi . [West Indies and Florida.]

vinelike.explanation: Resembling a vine or some aspect of one.

viner.explanation: A member of the Vintners' Company.

A structure, usually enclosed with glass, for rearing and protecting vines; a grapery .
a farm of grapevines where wine grapes are produced

a farm of grapevines where wine grapes are produced

vinous flavor; pertaining to wine or its manufacture.

Pertaining to or having the characteristics of wine .

vintage.explanation: The yield of wine or grapes from a vineyard or district during one season.

The year or place in which a wine is bottled.
The harvesting of a grape crop.
The initial stages of winemaking.
A group or collection of people or things sharing certain characteristics.
A year or period of origin.
Length of existence; age.

Characterized by excellence, maturity, and enduring appeal; classic.
Old or outmoded.
Of the best.
Of the most distinctive.
The gathering of the grapes; the season of grape-gathering; the grape-harvest.
The annual product of the grape-harvest, with especial reference to the wine obtained.
Wine in general.
The produce of the vine for one season, in grapes or in wine.
The act or time of gathering the crop of grapes, or making the wine for a season.
a wine fount.
the time of gathering grapes and making wine.
The yield of grapes or wine from a vineyard or district during one season

having an enduring appeal ; high-quality, classic (such as video or computer games from the 1980s and early 1990s, or old magazines, etc.)
of a motor car built between the years 1919 and (usually) 1930 (or sometimes 1919 to 1925 in the USA).

vintaged.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of vintage .

a person who harvests grapes for making wine

vintaging.explanation: The act of gathering the vintage, or crop of grapes.

One who deals in wine; a wine seller, or wine merchant.

vintnery.explanation: The trade or occupation of a vintner.

vintry.explanation: A place where wine is sold.
A place where wine is sold.

vinum.explanation: In pharmacy , a solution of a medicinal substance in wine; also, wine.
Wine, -- chiefly used in Pharmacy in the name of solutions of some medicinal substance in wine; as: vina medicata, medicated wines; vinum opii, wine of opium.

viny.explanation: Of, relating to, or having the nature of vines.
Overgrown with or abounding in vines.
Of or pertaining to vines; producing, or abounding in, vines.
Resembling a vine , especially in being twisty .

vinyl.explanation: The univalent hydrocarbon group CH 2 =CH, derived from ethylene.
Any of various compounds containing the vinyl group, typically highly reactive, easily polymerized, and used as basic materials for plastics.
Any of various typically tough, flexible, shiny plastics, often used for coverings and clothing.
Phonograph records considered as a group.
( on vinyl ) In the medium of phonograph recordings.
The compound univalent radical CH 2 CH, which appears characteristic of many ethylene derivatives.
The hypothetical radical C2H3, regarded as the characteristic residue of ethylene and that related series of unsaturated hydrocarbons with which the allyl compounds are homologous.
The univalent radical CH2=CH−, derived from ethylene
Any of various compounds and substances containing the vinyl radical, especially various tough , flexible , shiny plastics
shiny and tough and flexible plastic; used especially for floor coverings
a univalent chemical radical derived from ethylene

vinylacetylene.explanation: A dimer of acetylene butenyne CH2=CH-C≡CH used in the manufacture of some polymers

vinylated.explanation: reacted with an acetylene to form a vinyl compound

vinylation.explanation: Any reaction that forms a vinyl compound, typically by reaction with an acetylene

vinylbenzene.explanation: a colorless oily liquid; the monomer for polystyrene

vinylene.explanation: the divalent radical , -CH=CH-, formally derived by removing a hydrogen atom from each carbon of an ethylene molecule

vinylidene.explanation: any carbene in which the carbenic carbon is attached to another atom with a double bond R2C=C:

viol.explanation: Any of a family of stringed instruments, chiefly of the 1500s and 1600s, having a fretted fingerboard, usually six strings, and a flat back and played with a curved bow.

A musical instrument with strings, essentially not greatly different from the lute and the guitar, except that the strings are sounded by means of a bow drawn across them, not by plucking them with the fingers.
A large rope formerly used in purchasing an anchor: same as messenger
A stringed musical instrument formerly in use, of the same form as the violin, but larger, and having six strings, to be struck with a bow, and the neck furnished with frets for stopping the strings.
A large rope sometimes used in weighing anchor.
A viola da gamba , a family of musical instruments that preceded the violin and viola and similar string instruments
any of a family of bowed stringed instruments that preceded the violin family

viola.explanation: Specifically,in modern usage, the large violin, properly the alto violin, though generally called the tenor , in size about one seventh larger than the violin
In organ-building , a stop with metal pipes of narrow scale and ears on the sides of the mouths, giving tones of a penetrating, string-like quality.
A genus of plants, type of the order Violarieæ and tribe Violeæ , including the pansies and violets.
A genus of polypetalous herbaceous plants, including all kinds of violets.
An instrument in form and use resembling the violin, but larger, and a fifth lower in compass.
the tenor viol, or viola, a fifth lower than the violin. Its part is written in the alto clef, hence it is sometimes called the alto .
an instrument resembling the viola, but larger, and held between the knees. It is now rarely used.
an instrument formerly used, resembling the viola, and intermediate in size between the viola and the viola da gamba.

a viol, larger than the viola, having catgut strings upon, and brass or steel wires under, the keyboard. These, sounding sympathetically with the strings, yield a peculiarly soft and silvery sound. It is now seldom used.
Any of several flowering plants , of the genus Viola , including the violets and pansies .
A stringed instrument of the violin family, somewhat larger than a violin , played under the chin , and having a deeper tone
An organ stop having a similar tone
A 10-string steel-string acoustic guitar , used in Brazilian folk music .
any of the numerous plants of the genus Viola
a bowed stringed instrument slightly larger than a violin, tuned a fifth lower
large genus of flowering herbs of temperate regions

violable.explanation: Capable of being violated, broken, or injured.
Capable of being violated , broken , or injured .

violaceae.explanation: a family of order Parietales including the genera Viola, Hybanthus, Hymenanthera, Melicytus

violaceous.explanation: Resembling violets in color; bluish purple.
Of or pertaining to a natural order of plants, of which the violet is the type. It contains about twenty genera and two hundred and fifty species.

violan.explanation: A violet-blue variety of pyroxene from Saint-Marcel, Piedmont: essentially identical with diopside.

violaquercitrin.explanation: A yellow glucoside, C 27 H 28 O 16 , contained in Viola tricolor var. arvensis. It crystallizes in slender needles.
A yellow crystalline glucoside obtained from the pansy ( Viola tricolor ), and decomposing into glucose and quercitrin.
A yellow crystalline glucoside obtained from the pansy (Viola tricolor) and decomposable into glucose and quercitrin .

violate.explanation: To disregard or act in a manner that does not conform to (a law or promise, for example).
To do harm to (property or qualities considered sacred); desecrate or defile.

To treat in a violent manner; to abuse.

To commit rape on; to ravish; to outrage.

violaters.explanation: Plural form of violater (alternative spelling of violators ).

violates.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of violate .

violation.explanation: The act or an instance of violating or the condition of being violated: synonym : breach .

The act of violating, treating with violence, or injuring; interruption, as of sleep or peace; desecration; an act of irreverence; profanation or contemptuous treatment of sacred or venerable things: as, the violation of a church; infringement; transgression; non-observance: as, a violation of law.

entry to another's property without right or permission

In the publishing and packaging industries, a visual element that intentionally " violates " the underlying design , such as a starburst, color bar or "splat" on a product package or magazine cover intended to attract special attention.

Extreme or powerful emotion or expression.

The unlawful use of physical force.

violer.explanation: One skilled in playing on the viol; also, a violinist.

violescent.explanation: Tending to a violet color; violascent.

violet.explanation: Any of various low-growing herbs of the genus Viola, having short-spurred, irregular flowers that are characteristically purplish-blue but sometimes yellow or white.
Any of several similar plants, such as an African violet.

The hue of the short-wave end of the visible spectrum, evoked in the human observer by radiant energy with wavelengths of approximately 380 to 420 nanometers; any of a group of colors, reddish-blue in hue, that may vary in lightness and saturation.
A plant of the genus Viola , or one of its flowers; also, one of a few plants of other genera. See Viola , compound names below, and cut in next column.
A general class of colors, of which the violetflower is a highly chromatic example.
Any one of the many different small blue or violet butterflies of Lycæna , Polyommatus , and allied genera.
Locally, same as bog-violet .
A viola d'amore. Sometimes called English violet .
Dark blue, inclining to red; bluish purple; having a color produced by red and blue combined.
any species of Ianthina; -- called also violet snail . See Ianthina .
a name given to several kinds of hard purplish or reddish woods, as king wood, myall wood, and the wood of the Andira violacea , a tree of Guiana.

Any plant or flower of the genus Viola, of many species. The violets are generally low, herbaceous plants, and the flowers of many of the species are blue, while others are white or yellow, or of several colors, as the pansy ( Viola tricolor ).
The color of a violet, or that part of the spectrum farthest from red. It is the most refrangible part of the spectrum.
In art, a color produced by a combination of red and blue in equal proportions; a bluish purple color.
Any one of numerous species of small violet-colored butterflies belonging to Lycæna, or Rusticus, and allied genera.

an aquatic European herb ( Hottonia palustris ) with pale purplish flowers and pinnatifid leaves.

violin.explanation: A stringed instrument played with a bow, having four strings tuned at intervals of a fifth, an unfretted fingerboard, and a shallower body than the viol and capable of great flexibility in range, tone, and dynamics.
An emetic substance contained in all parts of the sweet-scented violet, Viola odorata. It has not been obtained pure, and is perhaps identical with emetin from ipecacuanha.
The modern form of the smaller medieval viola da braccio.
A player on the violin; a violinist: as, the first violin of an orchestra.
A small instrument with four strings, played with a bow; a fiddle.
A musical four-string instrument , generally played with a bow or by plucking the string. Pitch is set by pressing the strings at the appropriate place with the fingers.
bowed stringed instrument that is the highest member of the violin family; this instrument has four strings and a hollow body and an unfretted fingerboard and is played with a bow

violina.explanation: In organbuilding , a stop having narrow metal pipes, and thin, incisive, string-like quality. Tt is usually of four-feet tone.

violine.explanation: A blue precipitate obtained by treating aniline with sulphuric acid and peroxid of lead: same as mauve .
A pale yellow amorphous substance of alkaloidal nature and emetic properties, said to have been extracted from the root and foliage of the violet (Viola).
An emetocathartic alkaloid , of uncertain composition, obtained from violets

violinette.explanation: Same either as violino piccolo or as kit .

violinistic.explanation: Of, pertaining or proper to a violinist

violinlike.explanation: Resembling a violin or its sound.

A large stringed instrument of the violin family, but smaller than the double bass .
a large stringed instrument; seated player holds it upright while playing

violone.explanation: A 16-foot organ stop yielding stringlike tones similar to those of a cello.

An early stringed instrument similar to a double bass ; a double bass viol

violuric.explanation: Of, pertaining to, or designating, a complex nitroso derivative of barbituric acid. It is obtained as a white or yellow crystalline substance, and forms characteristic yellow, blue, and violet salts.

viomycin.explanation: An antibiotic, C 23 H 36 N 12 O 8 , produced by the actinomycete Streptomyces puniceus, used in the treatment of tuberculosis.
An antibiotic , of complex structure, derived from the actinomycete Streptomyces puniceus
a basic polypeptide antibiotic (trade name Viocin) administered intramuscularly (along with other drugs) in the treatment of tuberculosis

viosterol.explanation: Ergosterol activated by ultraviolet irradiation; vitamin D 2 .
a fat-soluble vitamin that prevents rickets

viper.explanation: Any of various venomous snakes of the family Viperidae, having a thick heavy body and a single pair of long hollow fangs, especially the Eurasian and African species of the subfamily Viperinae, which lack the sensory pits of the pit vipers.
Any of several harmless snakes sometimes believed to be venomous.
A person regarded as malicious or treacherous.
A venomous snake of the family Viperidæ : originally and especially applied to the only serpent of this kind occurring in the greater part of Europe, Vipera communis Or Pelias beruts.

Any venomous serpent except a rattlesnake; a viperine; a cobriform and not crotali form serpent, as a cobra, asp, or adder; also, loosely, any serpent that is venomous, or supposed to be so; a dangerous, repulsive, or ugly snake.
In heraldry , a serpent used as a bearing, some writers avoid the word serpent and use viper instead, there being no difference in the representations.
One who or that which is mischievous or malignant.
Any one of numerous species of Old World venomous snakes belonging to Vipera, Clotho, Daboia, and other genera of the family Viperidæ .
A dangerous, treacherous, or malignant person.
Loosely, any venomous or presumed venomous snake.
a small, slender, phosphorescent deep-sea fish ( Chauliodus Sloanii ). It has long ventral and dorsal fins, a large mouth, and very long, sharp teeth.

a rough-leaved biennial herb ( Echium vulgare ) having showy purplish blue flowers. It is sometimes cultivated, but has become a pestilent weed in fields from New York to Virginia. Also called blue weed .

a perennial composite herb ( Scorzonera Hispanica ) with narrow, entire leaves, and solitary heads of yellow flowers. The long, white, carrot-shaped roots are used for food in Spain and some other countries. Called also viper grass .
A poisonous snake in the family Viperidae .
venomous Old World snakes characterized by hollow venom-conducting fangs in the upper jaw

vipera.explanation: A genus of serpents, giving name to the Viperidæ.

viperfish.explanation: Any of several predatory deep-sea fishes of the genus Chauliodus, having a slender body and a large head with fanglike teeth.
A deepwater fish of the genus Chauliodus, a fierce predator with long, needle-like teeth and hinged lower jaws, found mainly in tropical and temperate waters.

viperid.explanation: Any member of the Viperidae ; a viper .

viperina.explanation: Colubrina . Also called Nocua, Thanatophidia, Venenosa.
Ophidia , containing venomous serpents related to the viper.

viperine.explanation: Of, resembling, or characteristic of a viper, especially one of the subfamily Viperinae, such as a horned viper.
Viperina , especially in the narrower sense: broadly distinguished from colubrine , more strictly contrasted with crotaline.
Tropidonotus viperina , colored much like the true viper. See cut under snake .
A member of the Viperina; a viper.
Of or pertaining to a viper or vipers; resembling a viper.
A harmless snake resembling a viper in form or color, esp. Tropidonotus viperinus , a small European species which resembles the viper in color.
Of or relating to a viper or vipers; resembling a viper.

viperish.explanation: In the manner of a viper .

viperlike.explanation: Resembling or characteristic of a viper .

viperoid.explanation: Like or pertaining to the vipers.

viperoidea.explanation: A division of serpents which includes the true vipers of the Old World and the rattlesnakes and moccasin snakes of America; -- called also Viperina .

viperous.explanation: Suggestive of or related to a viper.
Having the qualities of a viper; malignant; venomous.
of or pertaining to a viper

viraginian.explanation: Of or pertaining to a virago; having the qualities of a virago.

viraginity.explanation: The qualities of a virago. [Rare.] Imp. Dict.
