In botany , a wrapper or external covering of some sort; specifically, in Hymenomycetes , same as velum universale . Compare exoperidium . See velum , 2, and cut under Fungi .
A saclike envelope of certain fungi, which bursts open as the plant develops.
a cup-shaped mass at the base of various fungi
cuplike structure around the base of the stalk of certain fungi

volvate.explanation: botany , producing, furnished with, or characteristic of a volva.

volvelle.explanation: A small and generally circular movable plate affixed to an engraving containing a dial or lottery, and made to carry the index-hand or pointer; any movable engraving superimposed on another for the purpose of showing variations.
A type of slide chart, a paper construction with rotating parts, formerly used for organization and calculation in astronomy and other subjects.

volvocaceae.explanation: unicellular or colonial biflagellate free-swimming flagellates

volvox.explanation: Any of various one-celled flagellate freshwater green algae of the genus Volvox that form hollow mucilaginous spherical colonies of several hundred cells.
A small genus of fresh-water algæ, of the order Volrocineæ and class Cœnobieæ.
[ lowercase ] A member of the above genus: as, the globate volvox.

A genus of minute, pale-green, globular, organisms, about one fiftieth of an inch in diameter, found rolling through water, the motion being produced by minute colorless cilia. It has been considered as belonging to the flagellate Infusoria, but is now referred to the vegetable kingdom, and each globule is considered a colony of many individuals. The commonest species is Volvox globator , often called globe animalcule .
Any of the genus Volvox of chlorophytes .
type genus of the Volvocaceae; minute pale green flagellates occurring in tiny spherical colonies; minute flagella rotate the colony about an axis

volvulus.explanation: Abnormal twisting of the intestine causing obstruction.
Obstruction of the bowel in which a loop of bowel has abnormally twisted on itself.

volyer.explanation: A smaller boat that follows the main fishing boat .

vomer.explanation: A thin flat bone forming the inferior and posterior part of the nasal septum and dividing the nostrils in most vertebrates.
A genus of carangoid fishes found in warm seas.

In zoology and anatomy , a bone of the skull of most vertebrates; a membrane-bone or splint-bone developed in the median line of the skull, beneath the basicranial axis, primitively consisting of paired halves, which sometimes remain separate, one on each side of the middle line.
In ornithology , the pygostyle or rump-post; the large, peculiarly shaped terminal bone of the tail of most birds, consisting of several ankylosed vertebræ. See cut under pygostyle .
A bone, or one of a pair of bones, beneath the ethmoid region of the skull, forming a part a part of the partition between the nostrils in man and other mammals.
The vomer bone ; the small thin bone that forms part of the septum between the nostrils .
thin trapezoidal bone of the skull forming the posterior and inferior parts of the nasal septum

vomerine.explanation: Of or pertaining to the vomer.
Of or pertaining to the vomer .

vomeronasal.explanation: Of, pertaining to, or situated near the vomer bone between the nose and the mouth

vomica.explanation: An abnormal pus-containing cavity, usually in a lung, caused by deterioration of tissue.
The pus contained in such a cavity.
In medicine , a cavity in the lung, resulting from a pathological process, and containing pus.
An abscess cavity in the lungs.
An abscess in any other parenchymatous organ.
An abscess cavity in the lungs or any other parenchymal organ .

vomit.explanation: To eject part or all of the contents of the stomach through the mouth, usually in a series of involuntary spasmic movements.
To be discharged forcefully and abundantly; spew or gush.
To eject (contents of the stomach) through the mouth.
To eject or discharge in a gush; spew out.
The act or an instance of ejecting matter from the stomach through the mouth.
Matter ejected from the stomach through the mouth.
An emetic.
forth , up , or out.
That which is vomited; specifically, matter ejected from the stomach in the act of vomiting; an attack of vomiting.
That which excites the stomach to discharge its contents; an emetic.
To eject the contents of the stomach by the mouth; to puke; to spew.
To throw up; to eject from the stomach through the mouth; to disgorge; to puke; to spew out; -- often followed by up or out .
Hence, to eject from any hollow place; to belch forth; to emit; to throw forth.
Matter that is vomited; esp., matter ejected from the stomach through the mouth.
That which excites vomiting; an emetic.
See in the Vocabulary.
nux vomica.
To regurgitate the contents of a stomach ; puke .
The regurgitated former contents of a stomach .
The act of regurgitating.
the reflex act of ejecting the contents of the stomach through the mouth
eject the contents of the stomach through the mouth
a medicine that induces nausea and vomiting
the matter ejected in vomiting

vomited.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of vomit .

vomiting.explanation: The ejection of matter from the stomach through the mouth.
The spasmodic ejection of matter from the stomach through the mouth.
The action of the verb vomit
the reflex act of ejecting the contents of the stomach through the mouth

vomition.explanation: The act or power of vomiting.
The act or power of vomiting.

vomitive.explanation: Causing the ejection of matter from the stomach; emetic.
a medicine that induces nausea and vomiting

vomito.explanation: The yellow fever, in its worst form, in which it is usually attended with the black vomit.
The yellow fever in its worst form, when it is usually attended with black vomit. See black vomit .
The most virulent form of yellow fever .
The black vomit associated with the worst form of yellow fever .

vomitorium.explanation: A passage located behind a tier of seats in an amphitheatre used as an exit for the crowds
An area in which vomiting takes place, in particular a chamber supposedly used by ancient Romans to vomit during a feast so they could continue eating.

vomitory.explanation: An aperture through which matter is discharged.
One of the tunnellike passages of an amphitheater or stadium between the seats and the outside wall or passageway.

In architecture , an opening or passage, usually one of a regularly disposed series, in an ancient Roman theater or amphitheater, which gave direct ingress or egress to the people in some part of the auditorium.
A principal door of a large ancient building, as of an amphitheater.
The entrance into a theater or other large public venue, where masses of people are disgorged into the stands; a vomitorium
A substance that induces vomiting ; an emetic
an entrance to an amphitheater or stadium

vomitous.explanation: Characteristic of, or causing one to vomit .

vomits.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of vomit .

vomiturition.explanation: Forceful attempts at vomiting without bringing up the contents of the stomach; retching.
The vomiting of but little matter, or vomiting with little effort.
The vomiting of but little matter; also, that vomiting which is effected with little effort.
Repeated ineffectual attempts at vomiting ; retching .

vomitus.explanation: vomit , the product of an emesis .

vomity.explanation: Resembling vomit in colour, texture, etc.

vonsenite.explanation: An orthorhombic-dipyramidal mineral containing boron , iron , and oxygen .

voodoo.explanation: A religion of West African origin practiced chiefly in Haiti and other Caribbean countries, based on animism, magic, and elements of Roman Catholic ritual, and characterized by belief in a supreme God and a large pantheon of local and tutelary deities, deified ancestors, and saints, who communicate with believers in dreams, trances, and ritual possessions.
A practitioner, priest, or priestess of voodoo.
Deceptive or delusive nonsense.
To place under the influence of a spell or curse; bewitch.
Of or relating to the beliefs or practices of voodoo.
Based on unrealistic or delusive assumptions.

A common name among creoles and in many of the southern United States for any practicer of malicious, defensive, amatory, healing, or soothsaying enchantments, charms, witchcrafts, or secret rites, especially when they are tinctured with African superstitions and customs; especially, one who makes such practices a business.
The same title transferred by voodoos to a personal evil spirit supreme among evil powers.
plural The practicers of voodoo rites as a collective body.

voodoo dance (a violent indecent dance belonging to the secret nocturnal ceremonies of the voodoos); a voodoo doctor, or voodoo priest (the terms most commonly used in creole countries for any professional voodoo); voodoo king or queen (the person who, by a certain vague election and tenure, holds for life a local preëminence and some slight, authority over all voodoos of the surrounding country).
See voodooism .
One who practices voodooism; a negro sorcerer.
Of or pertaining to voodooism, or a voodoo.
A religion of the Ewe / Fon of West Africa, practiced chiefly in Benin .
Any of a group of related religious practices found chiefly in and around the Caribbean , particularly in Haiti and Louisiana .
Any sort of magical or irrational approach to a problem.
To enchant someone or something using voodoo
a charm superstitiously believed to embody magical powers
a religious cult practiced chiefly in Caribbean countries (especially Haiti); involves witchcraft and animistic deities
bewitch by or as if by a voodoo
(Haiti) followers of a religion that involves witchcraft and animistic deities

voodooed.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of voodoo .

voodooism.explanation: The practice and doctrines of voodoo.
The practice of sorcery or witchcraft.

A degraded form of superstition and sorcery, said to include human sacrifices and cannibalism in some of its rites. It is prevalent among the negroes of Haiti, and to some extent in the United States, and is regarded as a relic of African barbarism.
A religious cult , from Haiti , involving witchcraft and sorcery .
a religious cult practiced chiefly in Caribbean countries (especially Haiti); involves witchcraft and animistic deities

voodoos.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of voodoo .

voorlooper.explanation: One who goes ahead to reconnoitre ; a scout .

voracious.explanation: Consuming or eager to consume great amounts of food; ravenous.
Having or marked by a strong desire for an activity or pursuit.
Greedy in eating; very hungry; eager to devour or swallow; ravenous; gluttonous; edacious; rapacious
Wanting or devouring great quantities of food .
Having a great appetite for anything (e.g., a voracious reader).
devouring or craving food in great quantities

voraciousness.explanation: The state or character of being voracious; greediness of appetite; ravenousness; voracity.
an excessive desire for wealth (usually in large amounts)

voracity.explanation: The character of being voracious; greediness of appetite; voraciousness.
The quality of being voracious; voraciousness.
the state of being voracious ; rapacity or extreme gluttony

vorant.explanation: heraldry , devouring or swallowing: noting a serpent or other creature of prey.

voraz.explanation: A common name of Aprion macrophthalmus , of the family Neomænidæ , of the West Indian fauna.

vorhand.explanation: In skat , the eldest hand, the leader for the first trick; the one to whom bids are first made.

vorlage.explanation: A posture assumed in skiing in which the skier leans forward from the ankles, usually without lifting the heels.

vorpal.explanation: Having a special power making decapitation likely.

vorspiel.explanation: In music , a prelude or overture.

vortex.explanation: A whirling mass of water or air that sucks everything near it toward its center.
A place or situation regarded as drawing into its center all that surrounds it, and hence being inescapable or destructive.
Any whirling or gyratory motion; also, a whirlpool.

In the Cartesian philosophy, a collection of material particles, forming a fluid or ether, endowed with a rapid rotatory motion about an axis, and filling all space, by which Descartes accounted for the motions of the universe. This theory attracted much attention at one time, but is now entirely discredited.
[ capitalized ] [NL.] In zoology , the typical genus of Vorticidæ , containing such species as V. viridis

A mass of fluid, especially of a liquid, having a whirling or circular motion tending to form a cavity or vacuum in the center of the circle, and to draw in towards the center bodies subject to its action; the form assumed by a fluid in such motion; a whirlpool; an eddy.

A supposed collection of particles of very subtile matter, endowed with a rapid rotary motion around an axis which was also the axis of a sun or a planet. Descartes attempted to account for the formation of the universe, and the movements of the bodies composing it, by a theory of vortices.
Any one of numerous species of small Turbellaria belonging to Vortex and allied genera. See Illustration in Appendix.

a hypothetical ring-shaped mass of elementary matter in continuous vortical motion. It was conveniently regarded in certain early mathematical models as the typical form and structure of the chemical atom, but is no longer considered a useful model, having been superseded by quantum mechanics.
A whirlwind , whirlpool , or similarly moving matter in the form of a spiral or column .
Anything that involves constant violent or chaotic activity around some centre.
Anything which inevitably draws surrounding things into its current.
a powerful circular current of water (usually the result of conflicting tides)
the shape of something rotating rapidly

vortical.explanation: Of, relating to, or moving in a vortex; whirling.
Any ciliate infusorian which makes a vortex.
Of or pertaining to a vortex or vortexes; resembling a vortex in form or motion; whirling.

vortically.explanation: In a vortical manner; in terms of, or by means of, a vortex .

vorticel.explanation: An infusorian animalcule of the family Vorticellidæ.; ⟩ a bell-animalcule.

vorticella.explanation: Any of various ciliate protozoans of the genus Vorticella, having a bell-shaped body and living underwater on a slender stalk often attached to a plant or other object.
The typical genus of Vorticellidæ , having a retractile pedicel; the bellanimalcules.

Any one of numerous species of ciliated Infusoria belonging to Vorticella and many other genera of the family Vorticellidæ . They have a more or less bell-shaped body with a circle of vibrating cilia around the oral disk. Most of the species have slender, contractile stems, either simple or branched.
any of various protozoa having a transparent goblet-shaped body with a retractile stalk

vorticellid.explanation: Any member of the family Vorticellidae.

vorticism.explanation: A short-lived English movement in art and literature that arose in 1914 and was heavily influenced by cubism and futurism.
A short-lived modernist movement in British art and poetry of the early 20th century, incorporating elements of cubism and futurism .

vorticist.explanation: An artist who used this style.

vorticity.explanation: A measure of the rate of rotational spin in a fluid.
A measure of the spin of an air mass such as a low- or high-pressure weather system.
The state or condition of the rotating portions of a fluid in which vortex-motion occurs.
A property of a fluid related to local angular rotation

vorticose.explanation: anatomy , specifying the veins of the external layer of the choroid coat of the eyeball, the venæ vorticosæ, which are regularly arranged in drooping branches converging to a few equidistant trunks which perforate the sclerotic coat and empty into the ophthalmic vein.

vortiginous.explanation: Moving rapidly round a center; vortical.
Moving rapidly round a centre ; vortical .

vosgian.explanation: In geology , the Bunter sandstone of the Triassic system as developed in the Vosges Mountains, consisting of a lower division of unfossiliferous red sandstone, the Grès des Vosges, and an upper red sandstone, the Grès bigarré, with Myophoria and reptilian remains.

votaress.explanation: A woman who is a votary.

votary.explanation: A person bound by vows to live a life of religious worship or service.
A devout adherent of a cult or religion; a committed worshiper.
A person who is fervently devoted, as to a leader or ideal; a faithful follower.
A person who is filled with enthusiasm, as for a pursuit or hobby; an enthusiast.
One who is devoted, consecrated, or engaged by a vow or promise; hence, more generally, one who is devoted, given, or addicted to some particular service, worship, study, or state of life.
Consecrated by a vow or promise; consequent on a vow; devoted; promised.
One devoted, consecrated, or engaged by a vow or promise; hence, especially, one devoted, given, or addicted, to some particular service, worship, study, or state of life.
A person, such as a monk or nun , who lives a religious life according to vows they have made
A devotee of a particular religion or cult
Someone who is devoted to a particular pursuit etc; an enthusiast .
a devoted (almost religiously so) adherent of a cause or person or activity
one bound by vows to a religion or life of worship or service
a priest or priestess (or consecrated worshipper) in a non-Christian religion or cult

vote.explanation: A formal expression of preference for a candidate for office or for a proposed resolution of an issue.
The act of voting.
A means by which such a preference is made known, such as a raised hand or a marked ballot.
The number of votes cast in an election or to resolve an issue.
A group of voters alike in some way.
The result of an election or referendum.
The right to participate as a voter; suffrage.
To express one's preference for a candidate or for a proposed resolution of an issue; cast a vote.
To express a choice or an opinion.
To express one's preference for by vote.
To decide the disposition of by vote, as by electing or defeating.
To bring into existence or make available by vote.
To be guided by in voting.
To declare or pronounce by general consent.
To state as a preference or opinion.
( vote with (one's) feet ) To indicate a preference or an opinion by leaving or entering a particular locale.
voted the trip a failure.
An ardent wish or desire; a prayer; a vow.

A suffrage; the formal expression of a will, preference, wish, or choice in regard to any measure proposed, in which the person voting has an interest in common with others, either in electing a person to fill a certain situation or office, or in passing laws, rules, regulations, etc.
Hence That by which will or preference is expressed in elections; a ballot, a ticket, etc.: as, a written vote.

That which is allowed, conveyed, or bestowed by the will of a majority; a thing conferred by vote; a grant: as, the ministry received a vote of confidence; the vote for the civil service amounted to $24,000,000.
Expression of will by a majority; decision by some expression of the minds of a number; result of voting: as, the vote was unanimous; the vote was close.
Votes collectively: as, a movement to capture the labor vote

To express or signify the mind, will, or preference, either viva voce , or by ballot, or by other authorized means, as in electing persons to office, in passing laws, regulations, etc., or in deciding on any proposition in which one has an interest with others.
An ardent wish or desire; a vow; a prayer.

A wish, choice, or opinion, of a person or a body of persons, expressed in some received and authorized way; the expression of a wish, desire, will, preference, or choice, in regard to any measure proposed, in which the person voting has an interest in common with others, either in electing a person to office, or in passing laws, rules, regulations, etc.; suffrage.
That by means of which will or preference is expressed in elections, or in deciding propositions; voice; a ballot; a ticket.
Expression of judgment or will by a majority; legal decision by some expression of the minds of a number.
Votes, collectively.
See under Casting , Cumulative , etc.
To choose by suffrage; to elec�.
To enact, establish, grant, determine, etc., by a formal vote.
To declare by general opinion or common consent, as if by a vote.
To condemn; to devote; to doom.
A formalized choice on matters of administration or other democratic activities.
An act or instance of participating in such a choice, e.g., by submitting a ballot.
To cast a vote; to assert a formalised choice in an election .
be guided by in voting
a choice that is made by counting the number of people in favor of each alternative
express one's choice or preference by vote
bring into existence or make available by vote
the total number of voters who participated
the opinion of a group as determined by voting
a body of voters who have the same interests
express one's preference for a candidate or for a measure or resolution; cast a vote

voted.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of vote .

voteless.explanation: Having no vote; denied a vote or the right to vote.
Without a vote ; not allowed a vote.
deprived of the rights of citizenship especially the right to vote

voter.explanation: One who has the right to vote.
One who votes or has a legal right to vote; an elector.
One who votes; one who has a legal right to vote, or give his suffrage; an elector; a suffragist.
a citizen who has a legal right to vote

votes.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of vote .

voting.explanation: Having an associated right for the holder to vote as an owner of business.
action of the verb to vote
a choice that is made by counting the number of people in favor of each alternative

votist.explanation: One who makes a vow; a vower; a votarist.

votive.explanation: Given or dedicated in fulfillment of a vow or pledge.
Expressing or symbolizing a wish, desire, or vow.
Given by vow, or in fulfillment of a vow; consecrated by a vow; devoted
a medal struck in grateful commemoration of some auspicious event.
an offering in fulfillment of a religious vow, as of one's person or property.
dedicated or given in fulfillment of a vow or pledge
this sense?) of, expressing or symbolizing a vow; and by extension a thick cylindrical candle
a hymn or chant dedicated to a particular saint , or to the Virgin Mary
dedicated in fulfillment of a vow

votiveness.explanation: The state or character of being votive.

votress.explanation: A female that votes ; a female voter .

votyak.explanation: a member of the Finno-Ugric-speaking people living in eastern European Russia
the Finnic language spoken by the Votyak

vouch.explanation: To give personal assurances or a guarantee.
To constitute supporting evidence; give substantiation.
To substantiate by supplying evidence; prove.
To summon (someone) as a witness to give warranty of title.
To refer to (an authority, for example) in support or corroboration; cite.
To assert; declare.
A declaration of opinion; an assertion.
Approving or supporting warrant; confirmation; attestation.
law : To produce vouchers for, in support of a charge in account.
old English law , to call or summon into court to warrant and defend, or to make good a warranty of title.
To asseverate, aver, protest.
old English law , to call in some one to make good his alleged warranty of title; be surety or guaranty.
To bear witness; to give testimony or full attestation.
To assert; to aver; to declare.
Warrant; attestation.
To call; to summon.
To call upon to witness; to obtest.
To warrant; to maintain by affirmations; to attest; to affirm; to avouch.
To back; to support; to confirm; to establish.
To call into court to warrant and defend, or to make good a warranty of title.
To take responsibility for; to express confidence in; to witness ; to obtest .
To warrant; to maintain by affirmations; to attest; to affirm; to avouch.
To back; to support; to confirm.
To call into court to warrant and defend, or to make good a warranty of title.
To bear witness; to give testimony or full attestation.
To assert; to aver; to declare.
Warrant ; attestation .
give personal assurance; guarantee
give supporting evidence
give surety or assume responsibility
summon (a vouchee) into court to warrant or defend a title

vouched.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of vouch .

vouchee.explanation: In law , the person who is vouched or summoned in a writ of right.
The person who is vouched, or called into court to support or make good his warranty of title in the process of common recovery.
The person who is vouched , or called into court to support or make good his warranty of title in the process of common recovery.
(law) a person called into court to defend a title

voucher.explanation: A piece of substantiating evidence; a proof.
A written record of expenditure, disbursement, or completed transaction.
A written authorization or certificate, especially one exchangeable for cash or representing a credit against future expenditures.
To substantiate or authenticate with evidence.
To prepare a voucher for.
To issue a voucher to.
One who vouchės, or gives attestation or confirmation; one who is surety for another.

A book, paper, document, or stamp which serves to prove the truth of accounts, or to confirm and establish facts of any kind; specifically, a receipt or other written evidence of the payment of money.

In old English law : The tenant in a writ of right; one who called in another to establish his warranty of title. In common recoveries there might be a single voucher or double vouchers. [Also written vouchor .] The calling in of a person to vouch.
One who vouches, or gives witness or full attestation, to anything.
A book, paper, or document which serves to vouch the truth of accounts, or to confirm and establish facts of any kind; also, any acquittance or receipt showing the payment of a debt.
The act of calling in a person to make good his warranty of title in the old form of action for the recovery of lands.
The tenant in a writ of right; one who calls in another to establish his warranty of title. In common recoveries, there may be a single voucher or double vouchers .

A document attesting to a credit against certain defined expenditures; a recipt for prepayment; -- often used in pre-arranged travel plans, to provide evidence of pre-payment of the cost of lodging, transportation, or meals.
A piece of paper that entitles the holder to a discount, or that can be exchanged for goods and services.
A receipt .
A person who vouches .
To establish the authenticity of; to vouch for.
To provide a vouch for (an expenditure).
To provide (a beneficiary) with a voucher.
a negotiable certificate that can be detached and redeemed as needed
someone who vouches for another or for the correctness of a statement
a document that serves as evidence of some expenditure

vouchered.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of voucher .

vouchers.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of voucher .

vouches.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of vouch .

vouchment.explanation: A declaration or affirmation; a solemn assertion.

vouchsafe.explanation: To condescend to grant or bestow (something).
To condescend; to deign; to yield; to descend or stoop.
To condescend to grant; to concede; to bestow.
To receive or accept in condescension.
To graciously give, to condescendingly grant a right, benefit, outcome, etc.; to deign to acknowledge .

vouchsafed.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of vouchsafe .

vouchsafement.explanation: The act of vouchsafing, or that which is vouchsafed; a gift or grant in condescension.
The act of vouchsafing, or that which is vouchsafed; a gift or grant in condescension.
That which is vouchsafed; a gift or grant in condescension .

vouchsafes.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of vouchsafe .

vouge.explanation: a kind of pike used by foot soldiers in the 14th century

voulge.explanation: A weapon consisting of a blade fitted on a long handle or staff, used by the foot-soldiers of the fourteenth century and later.
A medieval poleaxe bearing resemblance to a glaive or a Lochaber ax , although the blade portion is somewhat more elongated.

voussoir.explanation: One of the wedge-shaped stones forming the curved parts of an arch or vaulted ceiling.
In architecture , a stone in the shape of a truncated wedge, which forms part of an arch.
One of the wedgelike stones of which an arch is composed.
One of a series of wedge - shaped bricks forming an arch or vault .
wedge-shaped stone building block used in constructing an arch or vault

vow.explanation: To declare or assert.
An earnest promise to perform a specified act or behave in a certain manner, especially a solemn promise to live and act in accordance with the rules of a religious order.
To promise solemnly; pledge. synonym : promise .
To make a pledge or threat to undertake.
To make a vow; promise.
A solemn promise; an engagement solemnly entered into.

A promise to follow out some line of conduct, or to consecrate or devote one's self wholly or in part for a longer or shorter time to some act or service; a pledge of fidelity or constancy: as, a marriage vow.
A solemn asseveration or declaration; a positive assertion.
A votive offering; an ex-voto.

A solemn promise made to God, or to some deity; an act by which one consecrates or devotes himself, absolutely or conditionally, wholly or in part, for a longer or shorter time, to some act, service, or condition; a devotion of one's possessions.
Specifically, a promise of fidelity; a pledge of love or affection.
To make a vow, or solemn promise.
To give, consecrate, or dedicate to God, or to some deity, by a solemn promise; to devote; to promise solemnly.
To assert solemnly; to asseverate.
A solemn promise to perform some act , or behave in a specified manner, especially a promise to live and act in accordance with the rules of a religious order .
A declaration or assertion .
To make a vow.
To declare publicly that one made a vow, usually to show one's determination or to announce an act of retaliation.
dedicate to a deity by a vow
make a vow; promise
a solemn pledge (to oneself or to another or to a deity) to do something or to behave in a certain manner

vowed.explanation: Undertaken in accordance with a vow ; solemnly promised.

vowel.explanation: A speech sound, such as (ē) or (ĭ), created by the relatively free passage of breath through the larynx and oral cavity, usually forming the most prominent and central sound of a syllable.
A letter, such as a, e, i, o, u, and sometimes y in the English alphabet, that represents a vowel.
The vowel-points, except holem and shuruk, are written below the consonants. The holem is placed above the letter, and the dot of the shuruk within the letter vau to the left .

One of the openest, most resonant, and continuable sounds uttered by the voice in the process of speaking; a sound in which the element of tone, though modified and differentiated by positions of the mouth-organs, is predominant; a tone-sound, as distinguished from a fricative (in which a rustling between closely approximated organs is the predominant element), from a mute (in which the explosion of a closure is characteristic), and so on.
The letter or character which represents such a sound
Of or pertaining to a vowel; vocal.

A vocal, or sometimes a whispered, sound modified by resonance in the oral passage, the peculiar resonance in each case giving to each several vowel its distinctive character or quality as a sound of speech; -- distinguished from a consonant in that the latter, whether made with or without vocality, derives its character in every case from some kind of obstructive action by the mouth organs. Also, a letter or character which represents such a sound. See Guide to Pronunciation , §§ 5, 146-149.
A sound produced by the vocal cords with relatively little restriction of the oral cavity , forming the prominent sound of a syllable .
A letter representing the sound of vowel; in English, the vowels are a, e, i, o and u, and sometimes y.
a letter of the alphabet standing for a spoken vowel
a speech sound made with the vocal tract open

vowelist.explanation: One who is addicted to vowelism.

vowelization.explanation: In Arabic and Hebrew - supplying the vowels (diacritics), normally not written to show the correct pronunciation, used in dictionaries, children's books, religious texts and textbooks for learners. Arabic terms: tashkiil (تشكيل), taHriik (تحريك) - (action of supplying the vowel points) , also known as ḥarakāt ( حركات — the singular is ḥaraka حركة ) - (the diacritical marks), Hebrew term: ניקוד nikud.

vowelize.explanation: To give the quality, sound, or office of a vowel to.
To give the quality, sound, or office of a vowel to.

vowelized.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of vowelize .

vowelizes.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of vowelize .

vowelled.explanation: Having (a specified type or number of) vowels

vowellessness.explanation: The state of being without vowels , condition of being vowelless .

vowellike.explanation: having characteristics of a vowel sound

voyage.explanation: A long journey to a foreign or distant place, especially by sea.
The events of a journey of exploration or discovery considered as material for a narrative.
Such a narrative.
To make a voyage.
To sail across; traverse.

Formerly, a passage or journey by land or by sea; now only a journey or passage by sea or water from one place, port, or country to another, especially a passing or journey by water to a distant place or country: as, a voyage to India.
plural A book of voyages: used like travels .
The practice of traveling.
A way or course taken; an attempt or undertaking; an enterprise; an expedition.
= Syn. 1. Trip, Excursion , etc. (see journey ), cruise, sail.
To take a voyage; especially, to sail or pass by water.
To travel; to pass over; to traverse.

Formerly, a passage either by sea or land; a journey, in general; but not chiefly limited to a passing by sea or water from one place, port, or country, to another; especially, a passing or journey by water to a distant place or country.
The act or practice of traveling.
Course; way.
A long journey ; especially by ship.
To go on a long journey .
an act of traveling by water
a journey to some distant place
travel on water propelled by wind or by other means

voyageable.explanation: That may be sailed over, as water or air; navigable.
That may be sailed over; navigable .

voyager.explanation: One who voyages; one who sails or passes by sea or water.
One who voyages; one who sails or passes by sea or water.

voyages.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of voyage .

voyageur.explanation: A woodsman, boatman, or guide employed by a fur company to transport goods and supplies between remote stations in Canada or the US Northwest.

The Canadian name of one of a class of men employed by the Northwest and Hudson's Bay companies in transporting men and supplies, and, in general, in keeping up communication between their various stations. which was done exclusively in bark canoes, the whole region formerly under the exclusive control of these companies being almost everywhere accessible by water, with few and short portages. These men were nearly always French Canadians or half-breeds.
A traveler; -- applied in Canada to a man employed by the fur companies in transporting goods by the rivers and across the land, to and from the remote stations in the Northwest.
A trader, particularly in furs, who worked (and explored) in the area of Canada and the northern United States from the 16th to early 19th centuries; they were often of Quebecois extraction.

voyaging.explanation: The act or process of taking a voyage; a journey by water.
Act of travelling or going on a voyage.

voyeur.explanation: A person who derives sexual gratification from observing the naked bodies or sexual acts of others, especially from a secret vantage point.
An enthusiastic observer of sordid or sensational subjects.
A person who derives sexual pleasure from secretly observing other people , especially when such people are engaged in some sexual activity .
An obsessive observer of sensational or sordid subjects .
a viewer who enjoys seeing the sex acts or sex organs of others

voyeurism.explanation: The derivation of sexual satisfaction by watching people secretly , especially when those being watched are undressed or engaging in sexual activity.
The derivation of satisfaction by obsessively watching or following sensational or sordid subjects.
a perversion in which a person receives sexual gratification from seeing the genitalia of others or witnessing others' sexual behavior

voyeuristic.explanation: of, relating to, or derived from voyeurism or a voyeur
of or relating to voyeurs or voyeurism

vraic.explanation: Seaweed gathered for use as a fertilizer or fuel .

vrbaite.explanation: An opaque , brittle mineral with chemical formula Tl4Hg3Sb2As8S20.

vroom.explanation: The loud, roaring noise of an engine operating at high speed.

The sound of an engine revving up
To move with great speed; to zoom .

the roaring sound made by a motor that is running at high speed

vrooms.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of vroom .

vs.explanation: Alternative form of vs. , often considered as British English .

vt.explanation: verb transitive or transitive verb (often appears in dual language dictionaries)

vug.explanation: A small cavity in a rock or vein, often with a mineral lining of different composition from that of the surrounding rock.
In mining , a cavity; a hollow in a rock or in a lode. Vug is the miners' name for that which geologists more generally call a geode. See geode . Also called tick-hole, vooga-hole.
A small to medium-sized cavity inside rock that may be formed through a variety of processes.

vugg.explanation: A cavity in a lode; -- called also vogle .

vulcanian.explanation: Of, relating to, or originating from an explosive volcanic eruption.

vulcanic.explanation: Of or pertaining to Vulcan; made by Vulcan; Vulcanian.
Of or pertaining to volcanoes; specifically, relating to the geological theory of the Vulcanists, or Plutonists.

vulcanicity.explanation: The quality or state of being volcanic .
The level of power of a volcano .

vulcanisation.explanation: process of treating rubber or rubberlike materials with sulphur at great heat to improve elasticity and strength or to harden them

vulcanised.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of vulcanise .
(used of rubber) treated by a chemical or physical process to improve its properties (hardness and strength and odor and elasticity)

vulcanist.explanation: In the early history of geological science, one who supported the Huttonian theory, or who was in opposition to the views of Werner. See Huttonian .
Someone interested in volcanism , the study of volcanoes .

vulcanite.explanation: A hard rubber produced by vulcanization.

The act or process of imparting to caoutchouc, gutta-percha, or the like, greater elasticity, durability, or hardness by heating with sulphur under pressure.
A process by which rubber is hardened using heat and sulphur .
process of treating rubber or rubberlike materials with sulphur at great heat to improve elasticity and strength or to harden them

vulcanize.explanation: To improve the strength, resiliency, and freedom from stickiness and odor of (rubber, for example) by combining with sulfur or other additives in the presence of heat and pressure.
To change the properties of, as caoutchouc, or India rubber, by the process of vulcanization.
paper, paper pulp, or other fiber, chemically treated, as with metallic chlorides, so as to form a substance resembling ebonite in texture, hardness, etc.
To treat rubber with heat and (usually) sulphur to harden it and make it more durable .
To desertify or create a xeric landscape

vulcanized.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of vulcanize .
(used of rubber) treated by a chemical or physical process to improve its properties (hardness and strength and odor and elasticity)

vulcanizer.explanation: Apparatus used in vulcanizing indiarubber. Also spelled vulcaniser .

The equipment used for the vulcanization of rubber
A substance (such as sulfur ) added to rubber during this process
someone who vulcanizes rubber to improve its strength and resiliency

vulcanizes.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of vulcanize .

and Ordinary , etc. See common .

Belonging or relating to the common people, as distinguished from the cultivated or educated; pertaining to common life; plebeian; not select or distinguished; hence, sometimes, of little or no value.
Hence, lacking cultivation or refinement; rustic; boorish; also, offensive to good taste or refined feelings; low; coarse; mean; base.
See under Fraction .
Debased , uncouth , distasteful , obscene .
Having to do with ordinary , common people.

vulpic.explanation: 3 O.COC (C 6 H 5 ): C.C(OH): C(C 6 H 5 )CO.O, contained in Letharia vulpina and in various other lichens. It crystallizes in thin, mono-clinic plates, or in thick, transparent prisms, and melts at 148° C. Also called methyl pulvate .
Pertaining to, derived from, or designating, an acid obtained from a lichen ( Cetraria vulpina ) as a yellow or red crystalline substance which on decomposition yields pulvinic acid.

vulsella.explanation: Pl. vulsellæ (-ē). A forceps; specifically, a forceps, usually with toothed or claw-like blades, used for grasping and holding any of the tissues, and also for removing foreign bodies lodged in the throat or other passages. Also vulsella forceps .
[ capitalized ] [NL. (Lamarck, 1799).] A genus of monomyarian bivalves, containing such as V. lingulata of East Indian seas.

vulsinite.explanation: In petrography , a name given by H. S. Washington (1896) to lava intermediate in composition between trachyte and andesite. A trachyte containing nearly as much labradorite as orthoclase. The lava equivalent of monzonite. Compare latite, trachyandesite , and trachydolerite.

vultur.explanation: A Linnean genus of Falcouidæ , variously defined.
(at) Including all the vultures of both hemispheres, Restricted to certain Old World vultures, as V. monachus.
a bird that is usually restricted to the Andean condor

vulture.explanation: Any of various large birds of prey characteristically having dark plumage and a featherless head and neck and generally feeding on carrion. Species found in the Americas are in the family Cathartidae, and those found in Eurasia and Africa are in the family Accipitridae.
A person of a rapacious, predatory, or profiteering nature.

One of sundry large birds, of the order Raptores , which have the head and neck more or less bare of feathers, the beak and claws less powerful than in most birds of prey, and which feed largely or wholly upon carrion.
Figuratively, one who or that which resembles a vulture, especially in rapacity or in the thirst for prey.
Any one of numerous species of rapacious birds belonging to Vultur, Cathartes, Catharista, and various other genera of the family Vulturidæ .
Any of several carrion -eating birds of the families Accipitridae and Cathartidae .
A person who profits from the suffering of others.
someone who attacks in search of booty
any of various large diurnal birds of prey having naked heads and weak claws and feeding chiefly on carrion
